story:
TRANSMOGRIFY: Sarasota's Premiere Arts Magazine!

Hi, I'm Erin Johnson, an artist, filmmaker and musician, and graduate of Ringling College of Art + Design in Sarasota, FL. A small dedicated team and I have been working non-stop for over a year to launch Sarasota's premiere arts magazine. Considering that Sarasota is an outstanding arts-city on the international map (and has been since the roaring 20's), it is about time that there is a local magazine dedicated to the arts! Transmogrify features artists, musicians, filmmakers, photographers, animators, fantasy and sci-fi illustrators, sculptors, graphic designers, architects, fashion experts, performance artists, muralists and many other creatives, with upscale design and editorial impact that highlights art as not just something cool to look at, but also as a society and reality-changing force of nature! Our interviews feature artists in their own words, with a diverse mix of art styles featured, and compelling content that readers of any age-group can appreciate.

Above:1st Edition cover art by fantasy artist Schin Loong.

The Impact - GRASSROOTS INDEPENDENT MEDIA BENEFITS THE COMMUNITY:

Sarasota is filled to the brim with brilliant artists of many disciplines. Unfortunately, the vast majority of these artists often fly under the public radar, because they are not featured enough in other area media, or due in part to narrowly focused arts curating, plus other factors.

One conversation commonly heard in and around Sarasota questions why talents of all ages are leaving for other places. Why do these brilliant artistic minds migrate elsewhere? TRANSMOGRIFY will offer artists a voice, recognition. With this recognition of artists and what's actually happening in the arts comes increased public excitement, awareness and understanding, which in turn contributes to a renewed investment into creative community, collaboration and innovation, thus an expanded cultural infrastructure to support diverse creatives. TRANSMOGRIFY hopes to provide a much needed stimulus that energizes the art scene, by filling a large but seemingly invisible gap in media arts coverage. As Sarasota continues to define itself within the international arts scene, diverse representation of artists and varied art disciplines is key. In an arts community, let's make art visible: in the artist's own words!

Transmogrify will illuminate to the world exactly what we have in Sarasota: an astounding array of brilliant creatives who are changing the world! This in turn will boost the local creative culture, quite possibly the creative economy, and enhance Sarasota as an already popular arts destination, while at the same time helping artists (of many disciplines) launch their careers in positive ways. It's about inspiring and building community while creating awareness of the vast amount of astounding creative talent Sarasota has to offer. We might even get a little controversial while were at it... art is full of controversy!

Since Spring 2013, we've talked with hundreds of people in Sarasota, from all walks, income levels, ages, occupations, and every single person loves our mini-sample edition of TRANSMOGRIFY, and the mission the magazine represents. Everyone "on the street" unanimously agrees that this magazine would be a positive addition to the local media scene. They love our articles too! 


Above: Art by Chris Marcet, plus exclusive interview with the artist.

Until people see a full-color magazine in their hands, they have trouble visualizing it. Once we print and distribute this 1st edition, with your help, people will know what TRANSMOGRIFY is all about! Readers and art lovers can decide for themselves!  

Some might ask: "Why make a print magazine? Isn't 'print' dead?" Hardly. People love to curl up with a good magazine no matter where! With the migration of many things to the Internet these days, and with all the time we spend pointing and clicking in front of a screen, there's nothing like a tangible, physical magazine to relax with, whether on a plane, at a salon, or at home. Combining this with insightful journalism and fantastic art of myriad styles, makes TRANSMOGRIFY print editions highly collectible (plus maybe a bit more lively and shareable than a flat pdf reader on your computer screen).

Those of us in Sarasota already may be aware of how lopsided the art-representation can be here sometimes. Certain styles are emphasized, while others become marginalized, no matter how brilliant or pertinent to society and arts globally. 

A thriving arts community needs independent media voices! By supporting this campaign, you make the magazine possible. TRANSMOGRIFY's journalism is 100%  free from corporate or sponsor control. We don't pander to advertisers either. This is about freedom of the press, freedom of thought, expression and freedom through art. 

Getting there in style: TRANSMOGRIFY features layouts and content different from the other magazines. It's not about art fluff in nice packaging either. TRANSMOGRIFY already has a backlog of high profile artist interviews, which puts it on the par with other national and international art magazines. These unique interviews are important to the arts, and society and so we must publish.      

We need your support! As collaborators with Internet capabilities, you have the power to launch this magazine - and in the process help artists get the audiences they truly need, inspiring thousands of potential readers (including international readership interests), who are eager for something new. New York, San Francisco, Paris, Los Angeles... many worldwide cities have art magazines with challenging and thought provoking content! It's time for Sarasota to have such a magazine. It's time to TRANSMOGRIFY! Sarasota will be TRANSMOGRIFY's spawning ground and we have big plans for future expansion as well. TRANSMOGRIFY features international artists because we live in a global community. TRANSMOGRIFY LOCALLY & GLOBALLY! However, the first edition of TRANSMOGRIFY, which we need help to print first before anything else, will be distributed exclusively in Sarasota for FREE (plus mail order)!

Check out the video above for more info!

Exclusive Interviews and Content:

Here are some of the exclusive interviews and other content the TRANSMOGRIFY team has generated (we really can't wait to publish them):

  • Don Maitz, Hugo Award and Chelsea Award-winning fantasy/sci-fi artist!
  • Bill Griffith, nationally syndicated cartoonist and creator of "Zippy"!
  • Interview with TV's Catherine Dent
  • Exclusive interview on the arts with Nobel Peace Prize nominee Dr. Izzeldin Abouleish!
  • Interview with modern fantasy artist Schin Loong
  • Interview with Sir Francis Schwartz, on art, John Cage, the Fluxus Movement, censorship and more!
  • On set, in-depth coverage and interviews with the cast and crew of "NO REAL THAN YOU ARE", filmed locally in Sarasota. 
  • Nancy Tong, Academy Award nominee, "In the Name of the Emperor"
  • Interview with Jeremy Xido, director of the award-winning documentary "DEATH METAL ANGOLA"
  • Exclusive coverage and filmmaker interviews from the Sarasota Film Fest 2013 + 2014.
  • Plus much more!

The magazine will feature articles for artists (and art lovers) by artists, as well as insightful columns and sections on how art relates to the environment, social issues, community, current events, and much, much more.


Above: In Conversation with Sir Francis Schwartz. Photo by Stephanie Brauer.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are fundraising in order to print about 5,000-10,000 full-color copies of the DEBUT ISSUE of TRANSMOGRIFY. The size will be about 8.5x11". If successful in our campaign, these issues will then be distributed throughout Sarasota at participating locations - businesses, salons, galleries, cafes waiting rooms and beyond. This is the #1 goal! The printing/publishing is the primary reason we are fundraising.
  • A smaller portion of the funding goal is to build the TRANSMOGRIFY website. 
  • If the campaign raises more than the goal, the extra funds will go to building and enhancing the TRANSMOGRIFY website, magazine distribution costs, small production & equipment costs, paying photographers costs, writers, and producing future issues (maybe limited edition lenticular/hologram elements on the magazine of we raise enough). 
  • Check out the perks below! >>>

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you love art and creativity, and want to see more unique arts coverage, spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr, your art blog, radio, TV and other creative places. 
  • Email your friends with the links (they don't necessarily have to be in town).
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Spread the word! Sarasota needs a magazine like this, and TRANSMOGRIFY does what no one else is doing in Sarasota!

Power to the people! TRANSMOGRIFY!

story:
Hello and thank you for taking the time to review my page! 

My name is Khymberlee and I am the founder and creator of Lipstick Radio which was established in 2006.


In April 2013, I dedicated my radio show Lipstick Radio, to helping push the Independent Artist Movement and thus 95% of the music I play is ONLY Indie Artists. We have such talented and gifted artists in our rotation and I have made it my personal mission to help get them the exposure that they deserve.


To assist with this, we have just launched our 1st Annual Indie Artist Awards -voting starts March 6th and winners to be announced at our live event in Los Angeles on April 17, 2014. This event will also stream live on YouTube. 


Click here to view our Nominees: http://www.lipstick-radio.com/#!indie-awards/c1zm2

 
Because of the previous station that my show was on, I was not allowed to have sponsors which meant that I had to fund the show on my own since the beginning. Although it has always been my love to do this and to help others, I am in need of assistance to continue this movement.

I am in need of funds to help with the awards show for the following:

  • Venue rental fee
  • Food for VIP area
  • Printed Program Booklets
  • Step n Repeat (print & delivery)
  • Awards/Trophies (10 total)
  • Flyers
  • VIP invites for music executives
  • Security for the night of the event
  • Valet parking


Any amount that you can donate will help our mission and movement. Thank you in advance for your consideration and assistance!

story:
ZINE LIBRARY // SCREEN PRINTING COLLECTIVE ON THE MOVE!

Calling all zinsters, screenprinters and DIY lovers: Roberts Street Social Centre needs your help!

 

Roberts Street Social Centre is a creative space for people to come together in Halifax. We are currently home to the Anchor Archive Zine Library, Inkstorm Screenprinting Collective and the Peoples' Photocopier.

Over the 7 years we've called Roberts Street our home we've hosted artist residencies; provided skillshare workshops; screened films; been a place for Food Not Bombs to cook; had back yard fires and punk shows; and held many meetings.

Keep all this momentum going! On May 1st we will be moving to a new home after being evicted from our current Roberts Street location.

We're really excited about the potential of our new space. We want to continue the programming we've built and start new projects too! Setting up shop in a new location comes with a hefty price tag. Our collective DIY ethic will be put to task with renovating our new space, but it all adds up! Our total fundraising goal is $10,000. Over the next couple of months we'll be introducing other fundraising initiatives too. We set a really modest goal on Indie-Go-Go so we need your help to surpass it!

Funds raised will go to:

- Ramp & retrofitting to make our new digs physically accessible

- Building materials to make shelves for our zine library, a loft area and walls

- New work tables for crafting, art and workshops.

- Inkstorm studio including: a washout station, dark room and printing area

- Renting moving vehicles

- Provide a cushion for increased bills, rent and repairs while we get back on our feet

This site is all about fundraising money but we are also looking for in-kind donations of building supplies, helping hands and the following appliances in good and working order: stove, mini fridge, washer and dryer.

 

 

 

--------------------------------------------------

media release:

Social Centre Calling on Community for Ideas, Money HALIFAX – Roberts Street Social Centre, a community and art space in North End Halifax, is appealing to the community for support after notice that their lease at 5684 Roberts Street will end as of May 1, 2012. The centre is asking individuals and organizations for suggestions for a new location and for financial support including donations or support securing loan or grant funding. "Community members have been supportive in the past, and we hope that new and exciting ideas will come from our appeal,” says Jill Ratcliffe, a member of the Roberts Street Social Centre collective. “But we are definitely concerned about finding somewhere affordable with rising rents and taxes in the North End.” Six years ago, the Roberts Street Social Centre was a private residence that held the Anchor Archive Zine Library. Since then, programming has expanded to include a screen printing studio, a residency program, a community space for workshops, movie screenings and meetings, and a resource for low-cost photocopies. The centre operates on a budget of about $34,000 per year. Programming will continue as usual for the time being, and the centre is exploring its options to ensure that programs will continue beyond the May eviction date. “Roberts Street has built ties in our community through welcoming people with free and low-cost art- and media-based programming,” adds Ratcliffe.“We do not want to see the north end become a place only for high-end development.”

story:
In 2010, ACTA Emeritus Board Member Vicki Filgas raised $20,000 from small donations (including piggy banks), to fund the first Selma Historical Mural, created by the renowned Chicano artist Ernesto Palomino.  It’s now a necessary detour off Highway 99 for anyone committed to both California’s past and its future.  The mural is also a key part of Selma’s push for beautification of its downtown through the arts. Exactly three years later, Selma has just opened its new Arts Center.

Inspired by Ernesto Palomino’s work, muralist, artist, and poet Ramiro Martinez is now designing and will be painting a 75 foot long mural for Selma on the theme of “No Separations”. Vicki is again spearheading the fundraising campaign, this time to raise $10,000.  About Ramiro Martinez:  http://kingsriverlife.com/10/27/the-manchester-... 

Vicki made significant contributions to ACTA’s work while a member of the Board of Directors, providing professional translations, hosting Radio Bilingue mariachi workshops and donating her time as a site visitor as well. In Selma, Vicki led curriculum based ballet folklorico classes and the ensemble Los Paisanos de Selma for over 35 years.

In solidarity with Vicki, her ACTA friends have created a mini-campaign hoping to raise $500 over the next month. Within the first hour, we've raised 10% of our goal.  We invite you to join us.  Donations are tax deductible through the non-profit Selma Community Enhancement Corporation, 1710 Tucker St., Selma, CA 93662.

story:
Our Story

Danielle Harth is a student at the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana and an artist from Lombard, IL who hopes that one day she will be a role model and inspire many people to be happy, use the gifts God has blessed them with, and boldly chase their dreams until they attain the success they have always wished for. Danielle has been painting since 2008 and at the end of 2011 she set goals for 2012 to expand her business through more exposure and participation in more showcases. It is amazing that she received a call in January inviting her to participate in the African-American History Bazaar sponsored by The Faithful Few to showcase her artwork.

The Faithful Few is a non-profit organization designed to empower children and young adults by offering programs that reduce stress, build confidence, educate and inspire. On Saturday, February 25, 2012 at St. Elizabeth Hall from 11am-5pm, The Faithful Few will be hosting the African-American History Bazaar aimed to celebrate Jesus Christ, African-American history, and also honor African-American Veterans.

What We Need & What You Get

For this campaign, Danielle Harth is aiming to raise $500.00 through ticket purchases and donations to cover the expenses of reserving a space in the show and material preparations.

Tickets are $7.00. Free for children under 13 years. Tickets can be purchased through this site. Your purchase will reserve your spot on the list for the event on Saturday, February 25, 2012.

Danielle Harth is asking for you to donate. Even the smallest donation will be genuinely appreciated.

story:
THE EXPEDITION HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED! ALL GOALS WERE MET. I'LL BE TELLING THE STORY ON MY BLOG OVER THE NEXT FEW MONTHS AT WWW.FOXSTUDIO.BIZ. THANK YOU TO EVERYONE WHO CONTRIBUTED!


Support a groundbreaking international artist’s collaboration! For the first time ever, American and Mongol artists will travel deep into a remote area of the Gobi Desert of Mongolia to observe endangered species and habitats.

 


HOW IT STARTED

My art career began in the late 1970s as a sign painter and freelance graphic designer and and then as an illustrator. Since 1997 I’ve been a full time oil painter. For the past four years I’ve specialized in Mongolian subject matter and, as far as I know, I am the only American artist doing so.

I conceived the idea for the WildArt Mongolia Expedition two years ago. I’ve been to Mongolia seven times since 2005, traveling deep into the countryside, seeing wonderful things, having many memorable experiences, taking thousands of photos and then coming home to create my paintings of the wildlife, land and people of Mongolia. I’ve come to love the Land of Blue Skies and want to give back to a place that has given me so much.

I have learned how much artists are respected and valued in Mongol culture and found that if I say “bi zuraach bain”- “I am an artist”, to someone, it makes a very good impression.

The WildArt Mongolia Expedition, as a Mongol and American artist collaboration, is an ideal way to support conservation in Mongolia. It will be a real expedition into an area far off the tourist track where even the traditional herder families are few and far between.

The Expedition maikhan- an authentic Mongol summer tent which served as our dining hall

WHAT WE DID- THE CONSERVATION CONNECTION

The Expedition took place between August 23 and September 10 of this year. We left Ulaanbaatar, heading south and then west to the Altai Mountains and Great Gobi B Strictly Protected Area, then turning north to a famous area in Mongolia called Sharga, and finally back to Ulaanbaatar.



Mongolia is home to some of last pristine wild lands on the planet and a variety of endangered species. The WildArt Mongolia Expedition featured four of those species: snow leopard, takhi/Przewalski’s horse, khulan/Mongolian wild ass and the critically endangered saiga antelope. We met and consulted with scientists who study these species learning about them and the conservation challenges they face.

Takhi/Przewalski's horses that Susan Fox photographed at Khomiin Tal in 2006. This is the third and most recent release site. The WildArt Mongolia Expedition will be visiting the first site, which is to the south at Takhiin Tal.

There is widespread grassroots support for conservation in a country with a land ethic that goes back over 1000 years. Mongolia is a place where I believe artists can really make a difference. The story of the Expedition and the art we create and share will raise awareness in both Mongolia and the United States about about the places we will go and why conserving them and the wild animals who live there is important.

WHO WENT?

SUSAN FOX

 

TUGS-OYUN SODNOM


OIDOVIIN MAGVANDORJ

 

SHARON K. SCHAFER

 

ODNA IDEVKHTEN

You can learn more about everyone here: http://foxstudio.biz/the-wildart-mongolia-expedition/


WHY I NEED YOUR SUPPORT

And now the WildArt Mongolia Expedition is about to become a reality- but with one fly in the ointment. Like artists in most places, Mongol artists don’t make a lot of money and Mongolia is still an emerging economy. I still need to raise funds to cover the costs for at least two of the artists. The perfect answer is to turn to crowdfunding here on Indiegogo, which also lets me share this great art and conservation adventure with you and the world, and that's a good thing.

Gobi earth road

Due to the remoteness of our destination, reliable vehicles, drivers and a guide familiar with the area are essential. I have used Nomadic Journeys for six of my seven trips (the first one was an Earthwatch project in 2005). They will handle the Expedition arrangements. It will cost about $2500 for each of the Mongol artists. This will cover transport in Russian fergon vans, their drivers, an experienced English-speaking guide, a cook, food and tents for almost three weeks in the field.

You can find out more about Nomadic Journeys here: http://nomadicjourneys.com/

 


Khulan/Mongolian wild ass photgraphed by khulan researcher and friend, Anne-Camille Souris, President of Association GOVIIN KHULAN, one of the Expedition's science resources and stauch Expedition supporter


WHAT I NEED

I am asking for funding to cover the Expedition costs of two Mongol artists- $2500 each. If the goal is not reached, your contribution will be used to cover as much of their costs as possible. If it's exceeded then it will be applied to the costs as needed for the other artists or set aside as seed money for the projects that will take place after the Expedition....the exhibition, book and multi-media presentation.

I think once you learn about the Mongol artists from the campaign video and my website you will agree that they bring a variety of exciting artistic visions to the Expedition.

I spent time with all of them last year as the result of an art event hosted for me by an Ulaanbaatar art gallery. The Expedition information was translated into Mongolian and distributed throughout the artists community. These were the four who came forward and asked to go. I’m very honored to have the opportunity to travel with them.


ABOUT THE PERKS

The titles of my perks are based on what the Mongols call “The Five Snouts”, the livestock animals that they traditionally depend on.  “Khadags” are the traditional blue offering scarves that are given in both appreciation of and to honor a person. It seemed very appropriate to me to offer them as a gift to everyone who is kind enough to support the Expedition. The felt camels and horses will be from sources that support local families and provide income.

Here are some examples of my field sketches and location watercolors from last year to give you an idea of what I will be doing this year.



Please donate generously to the WildArt Mongolia Expedition. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask.

And if  you would like offer further support, please share my project with your family and friends.

Links:


SUSAN FOX'S WEBSITE AND BLOG:

WildArt Mongolia Expedition stuff at my Zazzle store!

FACEBOOK WILD ART MONGOLIA EXPEDITION PAGEFACEBOOK PAGE FOR SUSAN FOX

TWITTER

PINTEREST

GOOGLE+

story:
First and foremost a huge THANK YOU for checking out my page!

Meet the characters! 

 

 

A little about me... 

Hi! I'm Tanya and I’m an artist/author. Random ideas are always flowing through my head making it difficult for me to focus on just one....focus... focus...  

What is Buttons, Kings, and Strange Little Things?

Oh right, "Buttons, Kings, and Strange Little Things" is a collection of six short stories, all written in rhyme. Each page is an original painting which will then be professionally scanned and digitally enhanced! 

 

 

What does it look like? 

The book will be 11"x14" and it will have 100-110 beautifully printed full color pages with a hardcover. Being part of this funding means you are also part of the making of "Buttons, Kings, and Strange Little Things". I will post frequent updates, with pictures and text, and will greatly appreciate your feedback!  

(The text will eventually be inside the images... have to find the perfect font!)

What's the money for?

I have some initial funding as a head start, but I would like to give you the BEST quality book so I need to raise $5000 for productions costs. This money will all go towards printing, shipping, small prints, and art supplies. 

 

_________________________________________________________________________

 

__________________________________________________________________________

 

__________________________________________________________________________

 

__________________________________________________________________________

 

__________________________________________________________________________

 

__________________________________________________________________________

 

__________________________________________________________________________

story:
Hello, my name is Jennie. I am a student who has been interested in art from a young age. In grade school, art was my favorite class and I was one of the few kids excited at the prospect of indoor recess so I could sit and scribble my heart out. In middle school, a friend mentioned that my drawings bore some similarity to anime/manga. At  that point, I began watching classic shojo anime (Sailor Moon and Card Captor Sakura), and that is where it all began. Since then I have been watching anime, reading manga, and consistently developing and reshaping my artistic style. I laugh when I look at pieces I drew back then but acknowledge that everyone starts somewhere. I‘m proud of the progress, and I hope to keep working, learning, and improving in the coming years. I’d also like to branch out and experiment with various styles and mediums.

The past two years, I’ve been attending Anime Boston and spending most of my time in Artist’s Alley, the venue in which artists of all skill levels, styles, and mediums can display and sell their work. From the mélange of clothing, accessories, prints, and paraphanalia, one class of items in particular caught my eye: buttons! What a great way to display and spread my artwork, small enough to post up everywhere and flashy enough to catch the eye. Also, the low cost associated with each individual button would make my work accessible to people of all ages, interests, and financial backgrounds. They‘d add flair to any thing you slap them on to. As such, I decided that this would be my next endeavor. Until I saw the cost of startup…

Due to financial constraints, I am neither able to fund this project myself nor with my family‘s assistance.

As I’ve broken it down, I will need: 

  • 1-1/4" Button Machine
  • 1-1/4" Graphic Punch Cutter
  • Supplies to make 500 1-1/4” Pinback Buttons

Including shipping, this set totals around $400, but my goal is $500, a figure that meets Indiegogo’s minimum goal and accounts for associated fees.  If I reach even half of my goal, I will have enough to buy the machine alone. It doesn't sound fun to have to cut out perfect circles, but I'd be immensely ggrateful even so. Afte rall, artists suffer for their work, right? XD

I hope to sell these buttons online on a website such as Etsy or Storenvy. However, my main goal is to get a booth in the Artist’s Alley where I will sell these along with bookmarks, charm key chains, and other merchandise. If I am successful with these plans, I anticipate hosting giveaways from time to time via my art blog on tumblr.

Click the gallery tab at the top of the screen or go to my blog to see my artwork and get a better sense of my style.

I draw mostly in an anime/manga based style using copic markers or Photoshop. However, I do branch out and experiment with alternate styles or mediums such as watercolor. Follow or check back there throughout the campaign to view more button designs as they are completed.

Check out the right sidebar for rewards for differing donation amounts. They include thank-you's, items featuring my designs (or you may provide your own), commissions, and more.

For additional details on perks, please go here!

Shipping within the US is free.

International donors: Please e-mail me with your location so I may calculate postage.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are tough, and I acknowledge that not everyone is able to contribute. Regardless, I would like to thank you for reading this far. If you would still like to support my cause, spread the word! This would be extremely helpful, and may make or break this campaign. Sharing on Facebook, Twitter, or Tumblr would be great. Write something of your own or use the easy sharing buttons located above this description.

 

Questions? E-mail me at jrgb531@gmail.com. Thank you for your time!

story:
The Painting Guild is a new group at IU Bloomington, consisting of BFA and MFA Painting students, with a current bankroll of 0.  In order for this program to grow into an enriching experience for its students, it must obtain funds. All monies donated go directly to the visting IUB Painting Guild's Visiting Artist fund! Please help any way you can - it is much appreciated!

The Painting Guild is comprised of BFA and MFA Painting students. The visiting Artist fund will allow contemporary Artists from outside of the program to visit the students within the Painting program to provide studio visits and critiques. The Artist(s) will also provide lectures, which will be open to the University at large. This is a vital part of any Art program and one that our Painting program currently lacks.  Not only will the existence of this program benefit the Painting program at IU, it will be benefical to the entire University and Bloomington in general.

$1,000 is a small amount, just a portion of what we really need. We are hoping to multiply this amount many times over through further fundraising, but we cannot do anything without an initial sum of money. Any help is much appreciated!

story:
Summary

I am interested in addressing digital culture and its effects on human behaviour. The development of digital technology has changed the way in which humans interact with each other and the world around them. For many people their reality is virtual, consisting largely of interactions through digital technology. I am aiming to create a degree show that draws attentions to this concept by using digital projection to make optical illusions. Whilst also creating artworks that use the interfaces we are already immersed in to reinforced how digital technologies are becoming integrated into our lives.






If you would like to see more of my work and keep up to date with my progress you can see more at http://katychristopher.co.uk

Funding

To create the touchscreen artworks I will need to purchase tablets that will be altered and hacked to create he artworks. I aim to buy 4 of these each costing £60.56. I will also need to buy 3 projector mounts each costing £21.99. Along with this various materials will be needed to construct the forms on which I will project. Any money left after this will be used for business cards and promotion for the show.

I will be incredibly grateful to anyone who contributes any donation to this project and will thank you all individually. On top of my thanks I am offering various incentives from digital postcards to guided tours of the exhibition, which are listed fully below.

Your support and the money raise will help bring this show to life and help me realise my vision.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thanks for taking the time to read this post, I hope you feel inspired to be involved in anyway you can. It would mean the world if you could pass this page on in the various forms of social media that you may use. Thank you!

story:
About the artist

Andreas Schmidt is a German-born, London based photographer/artist whose work has been exhibited and published internationally. In 2005 German fine art and photography book publisher Hatje Cantz published his first hard-back monograph entitled “Las Vegas” to international critical acclaim. Described by J.G. Ballard as "the poet of the hotel corridor", his second book, 'The City' (2009), presents a photographic over-view of the architecture of London’s financial centre.

 

Over the last three years Schmidt explored the possibilities and boundaries of the artist's book and has so far self-published over 40 small books (7x7") in an ongoing series. During late 2009, he was one of the founding members of ABC, Artists' Books Cooperative, an international network created by and for artists who make print-on-demand books. https://abcoop.wordpress.com/ His books were last shown at Printed Matter in New York and in a group show called "From Here On" during Rencontres d'Arles 2011.

He lives with his wife and two sons in London, UK.

 

For an overview of his artist's books please follow these links:

http://www.blurb.com/user/store/auschmidt

http://andreasschmidt.co.uk/


About the project

Andreas Schmidt's new book Sponsorship (7x7", softcover, pages as yet unknown) investigates the growing phenomenon of on-line funded projects and the concept of sponsorship at large. The idea is simple: You sponsor the book - you instantly become part of an artwork. Pretty amazing value for only $ 5.

Please send your full name and a copy of your contribution receipt to mail@andreasschmidt.co.uk in order to guarantee your inclusion in the book.

For donations above $ 5 please also include your full postal address.

story:
My Story

Making chandeliers and lamps out of recycled glass

From zero to a sell out exhibition in less than a year with a small 25 year old second hand kiln.

Please help me buy a new one and also raise money for a local charity?

 My name is Janis Haves and I make lovely chandeliers and lamps out of recycled glass.  The idea came after I decided to make a chandelier out of bit of recycled stained glass.  A friend who is also an artist worked with me and it turned out so well I decided to show pictures to some local shops.  I spent the next 9 months, working on perfecting the design. To cut a long story short, (haha hard for me!)  a local gallery offered me an exhibition and then so did another, the second (a three month slot at a gallery/shop in Dorking) sold out within month. I have clients now and have been offered the change of two new opportunities to show.  I spoke to the bank about a business loan and they asked for a business plan.  I spent two intensive weeks working on it to be then told after I'd gone through the whole applicaton process, I haven't had my business account with them long enough for them to even consider me so I was turned down (which also goes on my credit record - thanks Lloyds!).  Such a shame, It's so exciting and I'm loving it, especially as I've been able to keep the whole recycled ethos central to the project. I hope I can build this into something really special.

 www.loverslights.com - click here for more photos

 What I Need 

The trouble the only kiln I I could afford was 25 years old, second hand and very small and though it's done a great job, it just can't keep up with the work load, so I just can't make enough lights quickly enough.

I would love it if you could help me raise £2000 to buy a new kiln?  The difference it would make to me would be huge and i can't tell you how grateful I would be for the support.

 What can I give in return?

I  thought a nice way of saying thank you would be to 'pay it forward'!
As a thank you for the new kiln I decided to christen it by making a large rainbow chandelier which I will auction, donating  ALL of the proceeds towards 'The Rainbow Trust'.  You can check them out here:

www.rainbowtrust.org.uk

 This is a wonderful local charity that supports families of terminally and seriously ill children.
I've also offered a workshop day to work with some of the kids to show them how to make some pendants of their own which we'll hang as part of the chandelier.
 I'll also give an 20%  'Angel' discount to everyone to donates who orders a recycled glass lamp from me this year.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word for me where ever you can?  Know anyone that enjoys art, supports recycling or would just like the whole idea?

story:
I work for a non-profit that fights domestic and sexual violence in the state of Oregon. I have recently expanded my area of interest to include forced marriages in Pakistani and Indian communities. A forced marriage takes place when the bride, groom or both do not want to get married but are forced to by others, usually their families. People forced into marriage may be tricked into going abroad, physically threatened and/or emotionally blackmailed to do so. Every year, hundreds of young people in the United States, both male and female, are forced into marriage against their will, often by violence and blackmail from their own families and relatives.

I would like to start my own small nonprofit to help these victims. This nonprofit will help individuals wanting to get out of a forced marriage, give them a safe place to live, and begin their path to freedom.

What I Need & What You Get

Initially, I am starting the campaign at $1500 to have a small office in my home but would like to buy an old house ($40k-$50k) and turn it into a shelter for victims of forced marriage. This place can be a safe haven for victims after they have escaped and will help them get on their own path to success and freedom. I will use mostly donations to furnish the house and might need around $2000 for phone lines and computers. These are just rough estimates.

I have many talents in graphic design but have recently discovered my passion for photography. I would like to sell my photographs to raise money for my nonprofit. I can send you a signed print in any size with a story of where the photo was taken. Per your request, I can also frame your photos and send them to you framed and ready to be displayed. Each photo will be endorsed by SP photography.

Ideally, I want to help victims of forced marriage start their life from the beginning and not feel hurt and alone.

The Impact

My project will be a valuable contributor to the world because not a lot of nonprofits provide services to victims of forced marriage. It is an issue that is not talked about enough. It is something I have learned about in my culture and know people that have gone through a similar experience.

I work in the field of domestic and sexual violence prevention, so I strongly believe that a collective voice makes a difference and small contributions go a long way. Most importantly, freedom from violence is a human right and should be acknowledged.


If you are unable to contribute, please read about this topic at the link provided and spread the word! Your voice matters!

http://www.forcedmarriage.net/whatis.html

story:
Short Summary

Hey Everyone. On behalf of The iseamonster Female Artist Collaborative , i would like to say THANK YOU for taking a peek at our campaign. We are a group that connects established and emerging female artists from all over the world on group projects and shows in Toronto Ontario. Our main goal is to create opportunities for up and comers to show in a professional space , and to work together with some of the most inspiring artists we can find. 

To see who iseamonster will be representing at our 2013 group show and to see images and videos from our 2012 year , please visit www.iseamonster.com . 

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to create enough funds to cover our gallery rental , promotional materials , the 2013 artist coffee table book , catering and bar. If we are really lucky , we will have enough funds to help our artists abroad with the cost of shipping their artwork.

We are excited to offer a few pretty nice perks. Including our 2012 artist coffee table book , and some pretty beautiful prints and originals from our artists. 

The Impact

The iseamonster Female Artists Collaborative is a really amazing portal for emerging female artists to get experience showing their work in a professional setting. As a lone artist in Toronto , getting started showing your work can cost a vast amount of money. iseamonster is a free portal for our artists , and a priceless experience. Not to mention, we have a lot of fun.

story:
Viva La Muerte! A tiny, D.I.Y. bath bomb business.

Hello! I'm Renee Bates, the owner and founder of Viva La Muerte! For the past three years I have been making organic, all natural bath and beauty products as a hobby for friends and family. Last year I decided that I wanted to start my own business crafting these wonderful, skin benefiting products so that I could share my passion for living a more healthy, eco-friendly life with the rest of the world. 
Starting a small business has been a slow process so far. I had to put my ideas on hold for a few months due to living in between America and Great Britain, getting married to the love of my life, and not being able to work in case it may violate any visa laws. 
At the moment I am back in America for the final stages of living with my husband permanently. 

What is Viva La Muerte! about?

Viva La Muerte! is inspired by a need for self expression and a need to feel closer to my heritage. The painted sugar skulls are a link to who I am, a person who cannot ignore the need to create something but also doesn't want to let go of tradition. When I'm feeling a bit homesick for Texas I can rely on working on these bath bombs which help me feel closer to my friends and family that I've had to leave behind. 

I first began making these sugar skull bath bombs at the end of last year. Why bath bombs? I love everything about them! I enjoy taking the time to treat myself to a bath and bath bombs add a delightful experience. Bath bombs are also a convenient way to add skin moisturizing oils and other ingredients to your bath without taking a long time to prep beforehand. All you have to do is put one bath bomb into your drawn bath and let it fizz! 
What I enjoy most about making these bath bombs is adding dried flowers and painting them by hand! It is a different approach to a common product which makes my sugar skull bath bombs unique. 

What I've done for Viva La Muerte so far: 

Other than creating and designing these sugar skull bath bombs, I have been embracing my strong D.I.Y. ethics to bring Viva La Muerte! to everyone else. 

  • I have registered Viva La Muerte! as a small business in Texas and will be selling my bath bombs at local arts and crafts markets. The funds that I raise through selling at these local markets will go towards buying more supplies and ingredients.
  • I have been keeping an online blog to share my progress and to post photos of my work.
  • I have a written budget and business plan for when I start my business in Great Britain. 
  • I have made, crafted, and designed nearly every aspect of my sugar skull bath bomb business (including labels, business cards, packaging ideas, market booth set up, etc.)
  • I have been labeling my bath bombs to comply with United Kingdom standards.

What this Indiegogo campaign is about and what you help me achieve.

If you decide to contribute to Viva La Muerte! you will be pre-ordering a fun, unique product. I'm not asking for a handout by any means! The purpose for this campaign is to promote Viva La Muerte as a small business. Your contributions will go toward all business related costs once I have moved to Great Britain. 

With your help I will be able to achieve the very first steps that I need to make to be able to sell my bath bombs to the public by United Kingdom standards and regulations.


What I Need & What You Get


I've been putting everything I can into Viva La Muerte! for the past few months. It is my passion to be able to bring something that I love to everyone else! I hope to open an online store via Etsy as well as sell my sugar skull bath bombs at local craft markets once I am living in England again. 
Before I can even think about being able to sell my bath bombs to the public I will need:

  • To acquire a UK trader's licence.
  • To apply for a VAT tax number.
  • To re-register my business in England.
  • To acquire business insurance.
  • To have my products tested for safety and also that they meet UK standards and regulations.
  • To have my designs protected. 
I will also need a small amount of funds to cover shipping costs when I send any remaining ingredients over to England from America. 
All of this budgets out to $2,000.

Stretch Goal:
If I exceed the $2,000 goal the remaining funds will go toward buying a high quality camera so that I can take better photographs of my products. 

Perks and Pre-ordering your Sugar Skull bath bombs:

In addition to your contributions you will be able to choose from several perks that are listed on the right. If you have chosen a perk with a bath bomb order please leave a comment stating which sugar skull bath bomb you would like with your order. Shipping costs are included with each perk. 

You may choose any variety from the eight designs I have listed below:

Margarita

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), rosa canina oil (rosehip), Rose water, Citrus bergamia essential oil (Bergamot), Citrus aurantifolia essential oil (Lime), mica colourants, dried calendula petals, dried rose petals

Burned Out Vato

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), rosa canina oil (rosehip), Rose water, Boswellia thurifera essential oil (Frankinecnse), Benzoin styrax essential oil (Benzoin), mica colourants

Rosa

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), rosa canina oil (rosehip), Rose water, Rosa damascena essential oil (Bulgarian rose), mica colourants, dried rose petals

Mourning Dew

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), rosa canina oil (rosehip), Rose water, Nymphaea caerulea essential oil (Blue lotus), mica colourants, dried chrysanthemum flowers, dried blue malva petals

Calavera Catrina

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), rosa canina oil (rosehip), Rose water, Chamaemelum nobile essential oil (Chamomile), raw locally sourced honey, mica colourants, dried chrysanthemum flowers 


Coco-Lime

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), Cocus nucifera oil (Virgin coconut), Rose water, Citrus aurantifolia essential oil (Lime), mica colourants, dried calendula flowers and petals

Wicked Mint

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), rosa canina oil (rosehip), Rose water, Melaleuca alternifolia essential oil (Tea tree), Mentha piperita essential oil (Peppermint), mica colourants, dried rose petals

Cool Jasmine *indiegogo exclusive*

Ingredients: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, prunus amygdalus dulcis oil (sweet almond), limnanthes alba oil (meadowfoam), rosa canina oil (rosehip), Jasminum grandiflorum essential oil (Jasmine), mica colourants, dried chrysanthemum petals, dried jasmine buds

When you order Viva La Muerte! Sugar Skull bath bombs you are ordering safe, all natural, organic, and eco-friendly products. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to make a contribution at this time, it's okay! You can also help get the word out about Viva La Muerte! by sharing this campaign with everyone you know.

story:
My Cat is a Jerk


About the Book:

"My Cat is a Jerk" is a children's book that takes a humorous look at the responsibilities (and rewards) of being a pet owner. Frank is a feisty cat who causes a lot of trouble, but, deep down, is a sweetheart. 

 

 (pages 1-4)


Background:

My cat, Frank, can be a real jerk. After knocking a full glass of water off the table one too many times, I decided to write a children's book about him.

I was spending a lot of time with my nephews, and began doing some collaborative drawing with them as a way to encourage them to draw new things. They had recently met Frank, so we spent a lot of time drawing him and the funny things he does. The drawings ended up being fantastic, and inspired me to collaboratively illustrate the book I had been writing.


Illustration:

As a recent graduate of Rhode Island School of Design,  I am lucky enough to have some ridiculously talented friends, who generously gave their time and energy to this project in exchange for hot chocolate and brownies.

We illustrated the book in an "art tennis" style. Meaning, each person was given a stanza of the book and illustrated it for about 10 minutes, and then passed it to the next person until it was done. It was super fun.


My amazing friends (whose work you should check out) are:

Ellen Alsop (RISD BFA Illustration 2013)

Hope Anderson (RISD BFA Printmaking 2013)

Esther Hong (RISD BFA Illustration 2013)

Maeve Jopson (RISD BFA Industrial Design 2013)

Thor Oren (RISD BFA Sculpture 2014)

Cynthia Poon (RISD BFA Industrial Design 2013)


Production:

The book is all ready to go! I’ve received print samples and they look fantastic!

My goal of $2000 is basically enough to purchase an ISBN for self-publishing, get 100 books printed, and give the artists something more than food as payment. And 5% of all money raised will go to a local animal shelter.


Perks:

NEW!!! Buttons!!!
for $5, you get a "My Cat is a Jerk" button, with a tiny little Frank saying "meow".


Digital Book:

For just $7, you get a PDF version of the book.

Prints:

$10 gets you an 8"x11" print. your choice of five illustrations (below). 

Softcover Book:

Earlybird $15 - Regular $20 you get the 8.5”x11” softcover book. 

Hardcover Book:

Earlybird $20 - Regular $25 you get the 8.5”x11” hardcover book. Ideal for children. 

Special Edition:

For $45 you get the Special Edition hardcover book - signed by all of the illustrators. wooohooo! 

For $65 you get the Special Edition hardcover book - signed by all of the illustrators + all 5 illustrations - signed. you rock! 

For $150 you get 2 Special Edition hardcover books - signed by all of the illustrators + all 5 illustrations - signed + a poster of the cover art - signed. you are pretty darn cool! 


Feel good about your contribution!

By supporting this campaign you are supporting talented artists, recent graduates, and entrepreneurs. Plus a portion of the proceeds will be helping animals in need.


Get the word out!

Have a kid? Have a cat? Love art? Get the book!

It’s ok if you can’t support at this time, but help us out by sharing our project with your friends and family!


Social Media

Frank is a popular kitty. You can follow him on Instagram and on Tumblr.

Frank is a feisty cat who causes a lot of trouble, but, deep down, is a sweetheart.   (pages 1-4)Background:My cat, Frank, can be a real jerk. After knocking a full glass of water off the table one too many times, I decided to write a children's book about him.I was spending a lot of time with my nephews, and began doing some collaborative drawing with them as a way to encourage them to draw new things. They had recently met Frank, so we spent a lot of time drawing him and the funny things he does. The drawings ended up being fantastic, and inspired me to collaboratively illustrate the book I had been writing.Illustration:As a recent graduate of Rhode Island School of Design,  I am lucky enough to have some ridiculously talented friends, who generously gave their time and energy to this project in exchange for hot chocolate and brownies.We illustrated the book in an "art tennis" style. Meaning, each person was given a stanza of the book and illustrated it for about 10 minutes, and then passed it to the next person until it was done. It was super fun.My amazing friends (whose work you should check out) are:Ellen Alsop (RISD BFA Illustration 2013)Hope Anderson (RISD BFA Printmaking 2013)Esther Hong (RISD BFA Illustration 2013)Maeve Jopson (RISD BFA Industrial Design 2013)Thor Oren (RISD BFA Sculpture 2014)Cynthia Poon (RISD BFA Industrial Design 2013)Production:The book is all ready to go! I’ve received print samples and they look fantastic!My goal of $2000 is basically enough to purchase an ISBN for self-publishing, get 100 books printed, and give the artists something more than food as payment. And 5% of all money raised will go to a local animal shelter.Perks:NEW!!! Buttons!!!for $5, you get a "My Cat is a Jerk" button, with a tiny little Frank saying "meow".


Digital Book:For just $7, you get a PDF version of the book.Prints: $10 gets you an 8"x11" print. your choice of five illustrations (below). Softcover Book:Earlybird $15 - Regular $20 you get the 8.5”x11” softcover book. Hardcover Book:Earlybird $20 - Regular $25 you get the 8.5”x11” hardcover book. Ideal for children. Special Edition:For $45 you get the Special Edition hardcover book - signed by all of the illustrators. wooohooo! For $65 you get the Special Edition hardcover book - signed by all of the illustrators + all 5 illustrations - signed. you rock! For $150 you get 2 Special Edition hardcover books - signed by all of the illustrators + all 5 illustrations - signed + a poster of the cover art - signed. you are pretty darn cool! Feel good about your contribution!By supporting this campaign you are supporting talented artists, recent graduates, and entrepreneurs. Plus a portion of the proceeds will be helping animals in need.Get the word out!Have a kid? Have a cat? Love art? Get the book!It’s ok if you can’t support at this time, but help us out by sharing our project with your friends and family!

Social MediaFrank is a popular kitty. You can follow him on Instagram and on Tumblr.

story:
Classroom on Wheels, a Teaching Trailer

I have been trying to retire for five years but love teaching too much to give it up. However, I will, unless my wife retires, we buy an RV and build a classroom trailer to travel throughout the 50 states, even Hawaii. I have been teaching Silversmithing and Lost Wax Casting for nearly 40 years and at the age of 68 (on April 20) I am just too old to be driving around by myself. I have taught in all but 5 states in the past 5 years. As I traveled to teach I found myself wanting to see things, do things and experience things, but passed the opportunities up because my wife was not with me. So, I just taught, ate, and went to the motel rooms in all 50 states in the past 5 years without really seeing any of them. Now, I want to visit all 50 states again with her before we are too old to do it!

She will retire, and travel with me, if we have a “big” RV, in her words, for a comfortable house on wheels, that she can live in, while I am teaching. We are shopping for it now. That will make her happy! I want to build a classroom trailer large enough to teach up to five students at a time in an air conditioned, heated, comfortable classroom. That will make me, and my students, happy! The plan will be put a new idea on my website for setting up class around all 50 states. Because I want to teach in all 50 states I will schedule a class for anyone that wants to learn Silversmithing, Lost Wax Casting, Sand Casting, Lapidary, glass slumping (cab making), art and crafts as we travel. All anyone will have to do is decide on a private class or up to 6 students and we agree on a weekend. The more students the less expensive it will be for each.  Please consider helping us fulfill this dream and check out the perks I have offered just for you and this project. Some are just for fun, some will more than pay you back for your help. If you ever wanted to learn any craft, as I have taught them all in public schools, this is your chance to start learning.

The plan is to purchase an 8 foot by 14 foot trailer and build it in myself. I will include the floor plan. I will have an entry door in the back with plans to have a wheel chair ramp that slides out much like the ramp they use for rental trailers and trucks. As you walk in there will be a restroom on the right, refrigerator and microwave on the left. There will a large sink right after the refrigerator and a place for an ultra-sonic cleaner and tumblers next to the sink.  I will build six benches, three on each side of the trailer with my teaching desk in the middle just after the restroom. This is the way I built my classrooms in the past. It insures that the students have to turn away from their work and listen better while I am teaching. I will build in a six inch buffer on the right just before the benches. In the front of the trailer I will build in the kiln, vacuum caster and broken arm caster. The trailer will be heated and air conditioned too. I want it to be a class room that everyone will enjoy coming to and learning.

I will be posting photos on my web site, learnsilver.com as we shop for the RV, trailer, and start building the classroom. I want to purchase all new equipment and tools for this new classroom and then let you come in and use it while parked at your house, business, campground, or even a Wal-Mart! Check out the perks that I have offered for your backing of this project, especially the private classes at your home. I am sure you will find one that will fit your needs.

story:
John James Audubon’s artistically stunning, scientifically accurate depiction of birds awakened generations of Americans to the intrinsic value of nature. The 435 life-size images drawn by J.J. Audubon for “The Birds of America”, the largest book printed in the 19th century, invite people into their mysterious world. Each brush stroke seems to strengthen the connection between humanity and the beating wings above. 

It is hard to imagine that some of the birds Audubon painted have become modern dinosaurs, among them the passenger pigeon. Billions of them filled the skies when 18-year old John James Audubon arrived at Mill Grove in 1803. Within his lifetime, the population would markedly decline, and by 1914, the very last of their kind, would die in an Ohio zoo.

Sculptor Todd McGrain has reflected on the extinction of the Passenger Pigeon, Heath Hen, Carolina Parakeet, Great Auk and Labrador Duck through the creation of five human-sized sculptures. His “Lost Bird Project” placed the original pieces in communities where the birds were last seen in the wild. Mr. McGrain will be honored with the John James Audubon Award for Art Inspiring Conservation on April 26th for his efforts to focus attention on the frailty of even the most common species. According to McGrain, “Forgetting is another kinds of extinction.”

Now, the John James Audubon Center has the opportunity to bring reproductions of The Lost Birds to the very place that first captivated John James Audubon. With your help, the sculptures will be installed for the summer of 2014, giving visitors an opportunity to see, touch and feel these creatures now lost forever.

Each dollar donated will be matched 100% by the generosity of one of the center’s donors. How often does an investment yield that kind of return? Help bring inspiring art to one of America’s most historic and inspiring landscapes.

This campaign is sponsored by Valley Forge Audubon Society, a partner of the John James Audubon Center.

story:
UPDATE 6/17:

 Endless thanks to the 25 people who brought us to our $1,000!

Now that we know we can afford a floor underneath our feet, we are excited to surpass our projected goal and budget in such vital components as plumbing (for a handwashing station), a killer ventilation system, an imposing stone, maybe even a proof/sign press or a photopolymer plate making machine to print images from digital files!

here's a "before" picture so you can see what we're up against:


The situation is simple: Our letterpress shop has been given notice to vacate our current space by July 1st.  Fortunately we have an opportunity to move to an off-the-grid organic farm across the river and up the road called Lunasea Gardens, where the owner has offered us a home, rent-free, forever!

The press and accompanying type cabinets will occupy a portion of an existing cedar pole barn built from lumber that was either salvaged, scavenged, or milled from timber felled on site.  Here's the obstacle:  it currently has only a dirt floor-- no good for a half ton Chandler and Price Old Style 8X12 job press!  We need to lay a vapor barrier, pack in some gravel, build frames, and pour a concrete pad so we have a good solid surface to work on and, most importantly, keep our beloved press nice and dry.

All of the labor to complete this task will be volunteered by us and our friends, and the money raised here will pay for the materials needed such as cement, lumber, and lighting.  Any extra funds will go towards making the shop as usable, comfortable, and organized as it can be. 

[led type inked up and ready to print]

Letterpress printing, along with moveable type, is the human powered technology once used to print all newspapers and books. Although over 100 years old and requiring no electricity as long as there is light to see by, the process of setting type and printing on a platen press such as ours remains elegant, and even by today’s standards is quite efficient.  It has experienced quite the resurgence in recent years by artists and designers attracted to the physical beauty of the relief impression. 

Who we are:

Travis Champ is a poet and songwriter who has letterpress printed many books on the C&P, including his own debut poetry collection Old Nehalem Road, and works by Matt Love, David Longoria, and Dusty Santamaria.

Sarah Archer is a poet and visual artist who has taught letterpress printing on both cylinder presses and platen presses at The Evergreen State College, where she learned the craft, and at The School of the Art Institute of Chicago while earning her MFA in Writing. 

Lunasea Gardens was established by Hank Tallman 2002.  All the infrastructure has been developed from the ground up, including roads, running water, and a solar electric system.

story:
Une collecte de dons pour le Fonds de solidarité du SÉTUE!

Le Syndicat des étudiant-e-s employé-e-s de l’Université du Québec à Montréal (le SÉTUEUQAM), section locale de l’Alliance de la Fonction publique du Canada, par la décision de son assemblée générale, est en grève générale illimitée depuis le 7 décembre 2015. Depuis le déclenchement de la grève, l’UQAM a gelé les salaires des étudiant-e-s employé-e-s et suspendu l’ensemble des contrats octroyés aux membres du SÉTUE pour la session d’automne 2015 et la session d’hiver 2016. Or, pour la plupart des étudiant-e-s employé-e-s, ces contrats constituent leur unique source de revenu. Cette situation met ces derniers et ces dernières dans une situation de grande précarité. Qui plus est, plusieurs d’entre eux et d’entre elles sont également des parents étudiant-e-s et se retrouvent d’autant plus précarisé-e-s compte-tenu de leurs responsabilités familiales. Lors de son assemblée générale du 8 janvier dernier, le SÉTUE a voté en faveur de la création d’un Fonds de solidarité afin de venir en aide à ses membres. Ce Fonds vise principalement à recueillir des denrées alimentaires afin de distribuer des paniers de nourriture aux membres du SÉTUE tout au long de notre grève.

Nous collectons les dons pour financer l'achat de denrées pour les paniers alimentaires du Fonds de solidarité du SÉTUE UQÀM, afin de nourrir (littéralement) ses membres étudiant.es employé.es.

Voici d'autres façons de contribuer au SÉTUE!
  • Faire des dons sous forme de denrées non-périssables que nous distribuerons ensuite aux membres du SÉTUE dans leurs paniers alimentaires hebdomadaires. Des boîtes de collecte ont été disposées dans les associations étudiantes de l'UQÀM à cet effet.
  • Partagez, partagez et partagez encore la page de l'événement sur les réseaux sociaux, parlez-en dans votre entourage! Ça fait vraiment toute une différence et nous vous en remercions grandement!

Des questions ou commentaires?

On écrit ici : solidarite.setue@gmail.com

Faire des dons sous forme de denrées non-périssables que nous distribuerons ensuite aux membres du SÉTUE dans leurs paniers alimentaires hebdomadaires. Des boîtes de collecte ont été disposées dans les associations étudiantes de l'UQÀM à cet effet.

story:
Welcome, welcome, welcome Puffers!  You have just stepped into the world of our newest Art Project!  Every year, we sit there and watch the big kids ride out of camp to deep Playa on their art cars, while we have sat around in camp since we lost the flying saucer.  This year, with the help of many people in Denver, some virgins with some very good skill sets, and the determination by a couple of our old crusty veterans, we will be presenting to you our solution to this problem.  For those of you who have been following the story so far, we have prepared a workspace and purchased a platform.  This project will take contributions from our WHOLE BPY FAMILY.  After many years of doing this, we know that projects like this cannot be finished without everyone's contribution.  "It ain't gonna Puff itself!!!" .  For the long and short of it, the Denver crew is going to build this and we need the international family to fund it.  This takes a massive amount of time and energy to create this kind of an art project. 

This plan involves several stages of construction.  We have finished the initial deconstruction, and are preparing to build the main steel structure.  Along with this build and this phase of production, we will be rebuilding the engine and replacing all six tires to develop a car that is Playa-ready.  Second stage will involve decoration, audio and sound installation, along with lighting.  Third stage will be finishing touches, deconstruction and packing for transport, and delivery to the Playa.  All of this, will of course not be cheap; two fundraisers will be conducted to get it there.  We need your support!  Please pass this to anyone you know going to the Playa or extended BPY family, and anyone that supports this kind of art.  This car will be a people-mover and camp art car, not a personal transport vehicle.  We need you, the people, to make this happen.  

Thanks

E-rock & Rickey Bobby

story:
My name is Samantha, I'm 24 years old and I have ulcerative colitis.

I was diagnosed in march of last year and experienced my first flare in April. In august I began showing signs of another flare however my symptoms were more severe. I had a job at the time and was having a hard time because I was having severe chest pain and headaches which normally I had not experienced. I went through 4 emergency room visits before I found out that I had developed an infection in my colon called c. Diff. I had to quit my job and give my body time to recover. 

This infection took a major toll on my body, I lost over 25 pounds and that included my muscles as well. I also had 4 blood transfusions and needed to be isolated at the hospital. It has taken a long time for me to get over the effects of this disease and infection on my body and would now like to begin designing and drawing as I had done before my diagnosis.

I am still unable to lift heavy objects or do most tasks for too long because I get fatigued easily and it makes it difficult for me to start working again. I would like to do something more from home where I am comfortable and won't strain myself.

Recently I have been creating designs that I would like to put on t-shirts but my supplies are very limited. I had a laptop with Photoshop but it was pretty outdated and the area where you plug in the charger broke. I don't have the funds to buy a new laptop and it is very critical to my design process. It is hard for me to commute and I am now having to drive to a friend's house to use their computer with Photoshop. It is not convenient and I would like to work in my own space.

I am really motivated right now to create as many designs as possible and to really make a name for myself. I never really know what my health will be like day to day so I try to use my time wisely. In the future i would like to have my own tshirt printing business and be my own boss. I would also like to use that as an outlet to spread awareness about ulcerative colitis and other inflammatory bowel diseases.

Here are some examples of my designs:

story:
ESPOIRS de FEMMES est une action menée par une vingtaine de personnes constituées en association sans but lucratif, dans le but d’aider les femmes seules et en difficulté dans le monde, en reversant les bénéfices de la vente du livre RECYCL’IMPRO à l'ONG ETW (Embracing The World), qui est l'une des plus grosses ONG caritatives du monde créée par AMMA.

Le livre de photos et poèmes RECYCL’IMPRO, qui contient 37 tableaux composés de matière de récupération,  s’inscrit dans les tendances à la mode comme le land‘art, utilisant des éléments trouvés dans la nature (écorces, branches, cailloux..) mais aussi dans la cuisine ou la maison (pelures d’oignon, miroirs cassés, vieux chiffons). 




L’art est déjà dans la matière. L’artiste les colle au pistolet sur de vieux placos de démolition et y associe des petits poèmes de sa composition. D’où le titre RECYCL’ pour les matières, IMPRO pour les poèmes.


Ce livre plein d’idées est un cadeau original. Il est une invitation à créer et crée lui-même des vocations à tous les âges.


Le deuxième aspect important de ce livre est sa destination : le bénéfice de sa vente ira en totalité à l'ONG Indienne qui s’appelle ETW (Embracing The World) pour aider les femmes seules en difficulté. Cette très grosse ONG a reçu un statut spécial de consultant aux Nations Unies et a été créée par une femme : AMMA.


Amma

Cette femme au grand cœur sillonne le monde et prend dans ses bras tous les habitants de la terre un à un, d’où le nom de l’ONG : Embracing The World. L’ONG est multitâches : elle construit des écoles, des hôpitaux, des universités, des maisons pour les femmes, des centres de formation … Elle aide aussi à la reconstruction après les grandes catastrophes. L’efficacité et l’éthique d’ETW ont séduit l’équipe de RECYC’ IMPRO. Ils ont choisi au travers de l’ONG d’aider les femmes seules en difficulté après de nombreux voyages (deux d’entre eux étaient hôtesse et steward dans des compagnies aériennes) et un constat : les femmes seules, par manque de moyens et  d’éducation, sont très souvent désœuvrées et ne peuvent exprimer leur potentiel, ou simplement vivre.

En participant à  la première impression du livre, ce sont ces femmes que vous aidez.

Confiants dans notre projet, nous avons débuté l'impression, et vos contributions permettront de la financer. Le livre est prêt. Merci pour vos contributions pour payer les traites de l'imprimeur, avancées par les membres de l'association.



WOMEN’S HOPE is an action conducted  by a non profit association of 20 persons, in order to help alone women in trouble through the world by giving the  benefits of the sale to the NGO "ETW" (Embracing The World) , which is one of the most important charity NGO of the world, created by AMMA.

RECYC’IMPRO photos & poems book, showing 37 compositions made up natural salvaged materials, follows a fashionable tendancy like Land art using founded natural components (like barks, branches, stones …) also in the kitchen or house (onion peels, broken mirrors, old cloths ). Art is already in the material. The artist glues them with a special pistol on demolition plasterboards and associates poems she composes. This is the reason of the title: RECYCL’ for material, IMPRO for poems.

This book is full of ideas. It’s an original present. It invites you to create and creates itself vocations.





The second important thing of the book is its purpose. The benefit of the selling shall directly be given to an Indian NGO called ETW (embracing the world) in order to help alone women in trouble through the world. This very big NGO received a special consultant status from the United Nations, and it has been created by a woman called AMMA. This kind hearted woman goes all over the world to embrace one by one all inhabitants of the world  (that is the reason of the title of the NGO: ETW meaning  “embracing the world”). ETW  does a lot of actions: build houses, hospitals, universities, women houses, training centers. ETW also helps building again after disasters.  ETW efficiency and morality convinced the RECYCL’ IMPRO team. They chose, through ETW, to help alone women in trouble, after many travels all over the world (two persons from RECYCL’ IMPRO team were steward and stewardess in airline companies). They noted that alone women without any money and education often have no work, and can’t express their potential, or simply live.

If you take part of our action, it will be these women that you help.

Trusting our project, we started printing, and your contributions will fund it; the book is ready . Thank you for your contributions, to pay the printer drafts, advanced by the members of the association.

L'équipe:

Hélène, l'auteure, a réalisé les tableaux et les poèmes

Helen, the author, made compositions and poems


Chidanand (Denis), le photographe, a fait les images des tableaux
Chidanand (Denis), the photographer, took the photos of the paintings

Jean René, le maquettiste, a fait la mise en page du livre

Jean René, the designer, made the layout of the book

story:
The photo you see is some airbrush practice work in the Trash Room I laughingly call my " Studio".

I'm George Webber and I've been an artist all my life.  I've done paintings, illustrations and cartoons for many nationally published magazines, T-Shirt companies and Trading Card companies and I've won several awards for my work.

I don't have a formal job with a paycheck but rather I support myself with my artworks selling them however and wherever I can these days.  Like for many the last few years of economic shift have taken their toll and now I find myself in serious need of materials and equipment in order to continue making art in this changing world. 

Not to sound overly dramatic, but the support of contributors like you could chance the course of my life for the better.

What will I be doing with your money?

A reasonable question.  The main things I'll be using the funds for will be:

  • Paints, inks, small tools such as brushes, pens, airbrush parts and so on.
  • Art Boards, Canvases, assorted Drawing Paper.
  • A Rolling Tool Chest - this is needed not just for convince of storing or moving supplies and equipment, but for security as well as I can lock up the tools and secure it in the location where I often work.
  • A upgraded Silent Compressor - the one I currently use is completely under powered for the job and is many years old. I do have access to a larger one but it is extremely noisy making working at night impossible.
To Reward people for their help and donations I have several Perks ranging from  "Thank You" postcards to art prints and original drawings, hopefully more soon.


What happens if you don't make you goal?

Regardless of making my goal or not, all funds will be going to the purchase of Art supplies and or art related tools.  So even if I don't achieve exactly what I hope to, any funding will help keep me moving forward to achieve my goals.


What effect will you contribution make?

Every dollar that goes into improving my ability to be productive and keeps me creating artworks has the potential to change my life.  Many many years ago my first sale of one of my works was only made possible by the purchase of a 49 cent pen,I could not have achieved anything without it.

No Money? Here's some ways you can still help.

Spread the word about my campaign, PLEASE, and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
