story:
Plants provide the materials for many of our greatest cultural achievements. This project aims to assemble a unique collection of the most outstanding artifacts made from plant raw material representing the extraordinary diversity of Human Cultures and Societies.

ABOUT ME

I am a biologist, with a PhD in Plant Taxonomy and Systematics (Ethnobotany), and also the founding-director of a Botanical Museum located in Beja (Portugal). Ever since I can remember, I had a passion for plants with an especially interest in the area that studies how Humans incorporate Plants into their culture.

Flowers made with fig wood (Ficus carica) from Azores Islands (Portugal). This art was traditionally made by nuns and when the convents were closed the tradition was kept by the local community.

OUR GOAL

With this campaign we intend to obtain funds to establish a world’s collection of artifacts made with plant raw materials that represents past and present human interactions with the Plant Kingdom and also a selection of natural objects (seeds, fruits, woods, etc.) that represents the amazing diversity of the plant’s world (as the coco-de-mer, Lodoceia maldivica, see head figure of this campaign which shows two coco-de-mer seeds). We are willing to obtain items from all contemporary human societies and cultures.

We believe that this campaign is very important because we can finally assemble, under one unique collection, some of the world’s ethnobiodiversity concerning the use of plants by Humans.

Basket made with cloves (Syzygium aromaticum) from Indonesia. Cloves are flower buds that did not have the opportunity to open because they were harvested in an early stage of flower development.

THE COLLECTION

The collection will be used to non-profit pro bono public education and a selection of item will be in permanent display in Lisbon, a multicultural city with strong historical and cultural links with plants, and temporary displays in New York. Besides these, the entire collection will be available in a free access website to promote the knowledge and the conservation of our ethno-ecological heritage and also increase the awareness concerning the artistic knowledge related with the wonderful objects that humans have created from plants raw materials.

We truly believe that this collection will increase the awareness for issues related with the safeguard of non-urban traditional knowledge, some of which is now facing cultural erosion or extinction.

Amber from the Baltic Sea is usually recollected at the beaches, especially after big sea storms. Baltic Countries has a long, rich and unique tradition of making jewels with amber, as this one from the Hermitage Museum workshops (Russia). Amber is a fossil resin that trees from several genus (Pinus sp. and others) produced millions of years ago.

THE ARTIFACTS

The objects included in the collection will be those that represent the ethnic groups or cultures who have created them, for example, the shirts made with pineapple fibers (Ananas comosus) from the Philippines, Australian aboriginal paintings made over eucalyptus bark (Eucalyptus sp.), indigo (Indigofera tinctoria) dyed fabrics from India and China; sculptures made with vegetable ivory (Phytelephas macrocarpa) from Ecuador; traditional palm baskets (Hyphaene thebaica) from Botswana; frankincense (Boswellia sacra) and myrrh (Commiphora myrrha) from Oman, and many thousands of other examples.

My academic and professional careers are based on ethnobotany (plants and people studies) and I have always nourished this project for the last twenty years. The contributors who decide to join us will be helping the genesis of a new world’s collection for perpetual public use and education.

All items shown in this page (and in the gallery) are already included in the future collection but I would like to increase its number in order to represent more people and human cultures from Earth as well as use them for scientific education (via web and exhibitions).

Vegetable ivory seed (Phytelephas macrocarpa) from Ecuador and UK Victorian sewing items made with vegetable ivory.

HOW MUCH DO WE NEED AND WHAT FOR

We need to obtain 250.000 USD to the following actions:

1. Assemble the collection, and keep it under the best conditions accordingly to contemporary museum standards (including preventive conservation measures).

2. Create and maintain a website with all the information obtained from our research (items and related data) in English and Portuguese.

3. Organize and maintain a selections of items for permanent display in Lisbon and New York.

4. Promote academic interdisciplinary research related with the collection.

If we are unable to reach our goal of funding, the money will be used to obtain items and maintain a web page related with ethnobotany.

We will begin working on this soon after the campaing ends (assembling the collection and design the new webpage). We are willing  to keep working on this perpetually with no date to end the activities, although the displays in Lisbon and New York should be ready in the fall of 2014.

Raffia tapestry from the Kuba People in Congo made with fibbers from the raffia palm (Raphia farinifera). Traditionally, these tapestries are made by men only.

HOW CAN YOU HELP

If you cannot contribute with money, you can help us in other ways:

1. Informing us about the ethnobotanical richness of your country/region/culture.

2. Spreading the news about this exciting and unique project.

3. Visiting our future website about this project and send your feedback.

We will maintain a mailing list of all contributors and will send monthly newsletters concerning the project’s activities. 

Never a project like ours has been developed. There was never a goal of assembling, under one collection, items and knowledge representing the world’s etnobotanical diversity - items made with plants that represent the Earth’s ethnobiological diversity. We truly believe this is a wonderful project with an exciting goal.

Hand carved coconut (Cocos nucifera) from Indonesia.

PLANTS - ART AND ARTIFACTS

Plants are the most important elements of the ecosystems (natural and agro-ecosystems) and for millennia they have been used as sources for material culture (baskets, cloth, dyes, resins, etc.). Our goal is to record, collect and preserve all the knowledge related with these traditions. We will use the artifacts produced by specific human societies to tell the history of the cultures that have created them.

Spices are very important cultural elements in many human societies. Here we have a photo with nutmeg (Myristica fragrans), Ethiopian Pepper (Xylopia aethiopica), Star anise (Illicium verum), Mace (Myristica fragrans - mace is the aril of nutmeg), clove (Syzygium aromaticum) and most expensive of all: saffron (Crocus sativus).

MORE ABOUT MY WORK

I founded the Botanical Museum in Beja, Portugal, which is one of the few in Europe that is focused in ethnobotanical knowledge - Plants and People Studies. Besides this I have written several projects about the uses of plants (currently I am the head researcher of a project with Kew Gardens that is re-evaluating the Victorian Age throughout the plants perspective) and I also wrote scientific papers on ethnobotany and chapters in books, such as:

Mendonça de Carvalho, L.; Fernandes, F. (2011). Exotica Naturalia – O Enigma do Coco-do-mar. Artis 9-10: 153-162.

Mendonça de Carvalho, L.; Fernandes, F. M.; Bowden, H. (2011). Oracle Trees in the Ancient Hellenic World. Harvard Papers in Botany. Vol. 16 (2): 421–423

Mendonça de Carvalho, L. (2011). The Symbolic Uses of Plants. In Anderson, E.; Pearsall, D., Hunn, E.; Turner, N. (edit.). Ethnobiology. Wiley-Blackwell, New York. (353-371). ISBN: 9780470547854.

Mendonça de Carvalho, L.; Fernandes, F. M.; Nunes, F.; Mills, C. (2012). The Queen and the Flower Power – The Symbolic Use of Plants in the Court of St. James, UK. Harvard Papers in Botany. Vol. 17 (2): 317–322.

My PhD thesis was the first one in ethnobotany granted by a Portuguese University (from Coimbra University, one of the oldest universities in Europe, founded in 1290).

Detail of a tapa cloth from Fiji Islands made with paper mulberry tree (Broussonetia papyrifera). 

I INVITE YOU TO SEE:

my web site:

www.etnobiodiversidade.org

my blog:

http://etnobiodiversidade.blogspot.com

my Facebook page (Luís Mendonça de Carvalho):

https://www.facebook.com/luis.mendoncadecarvalho

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate and contact me: museubotanico@hotmail.com

I kindly request you let your friends know about this project; they may wish to promote it and help us.

Please use Indiegogo share tools to make people know about this project.

Thank you in advance for your support!

Below, is a shirt made with pineapple fibbers (Ananas comosus) from the Philippines (pineapple is not native from this country but when it was introduced, there was already a long history of using plant fibbers, so it was immediately used - it is now used to make this outstanding shirt - the Barong - which is the National Costume of the Philippines).

Detail of a tapa cloth from Fiji Islands made with paper mulberry tree (Broussonetia papyrifera). 

I INVITE YOU TO SEE:
my web site:
www.etnobiodiversidade.org
my blog:
http://etnobiodiversidade.blogspot.com
my Facebook page (Luís Mendonça de Carvalho):
https://www.facebook.com/luis.mendoncadecarvalho
If you have any questions, please do not hesitate and contact me: museubotanico@hotmail.com
I kindly request you let your friends know about this project; they may wish to promote it and help us.
Please use Indiegogo share tools to make people know about this project.
Thank you in advance for your support!
Below, is a shirt made with pineapple fibbers (Ananas comosus) from the Philippines (pineapple is not native from this country but when it was introduced, there was already a long history of using plant fibbers, so it was immediately used - it is now used to make this outstanding shirt - the Barong - which is the National Costume of the Philippines).

story:
Dear Friends,

the reunion with a teenage friend from Afghanistan triggered my interest and engagement in Afghanistan three years ago. Like many other people, too, I knew nothing about Afghanistan, except what western media had been reporting through all phases of war and occupation. So I connected to Afghan people on facebook and started researching on music, film, people, language, landscape, and of course Art.


But I couldn't find anything useful on Afghan Art! I found mostly websites with dead links, broken images and outdated information.
This had to change. The idea for KABUL ART PROJECT was born.

When I received the first applications for the project and saw the strong and impressive artworks, I knew I was on the right track. I fell in love with Contemporary Afghan Art.

After one and a half year of promoting Afghan Artists and building up Kabul Art Project with lots of love, work and passion, I hope we can take the next step together with the same commitment and enthusiasm!

Those of you who know me personally know already how much Kabul Art Project means to me.  Thank you, dear friends and followers of KABUL ART PROJECT for your continuous support and encouragement.

Christina Hallmann-Baudys
KABUL ART PROJECT

Read more about Kabul Art Project below...



With your support of Euro 35,000 you will enable us

  • to start our KAP Artist Book series with one Artist Book every three months.
    The Artist Books will introduce the artists of KABUL ART PROJECT with their biography and a rich collection of their artworks with information and details.
    The books will be available through online stores in English/German for worldwide shipping. A special edition for Afghanistan in the two main languages Dari and Pashto will be printed in Kabul.
    Book details:  21 x 21 cm, 60 - 80 pages, hard cover, color print.
    Publishing start: December 2014

    The Book No. 1 is available as a Perk in a regular or limited & signed copy!

  • to publish the first KABUL ART PROJECT Catalogue, that includes a selection of artworks by all artists of Kabul Art Project, artist info and artwork details. A portfolio of the Contemporary Afghan Art of KABUL ART PROJECT, with words and comments by artists and experts.
    Catalogue details: 21 x 29,7 cm, 148 pages, hard cover, color print
    Language: English
  • to open our KAP Online Store
    Our Catalogue, the Artist Books, high quality Art Prints and Original Artworks will be available there in an easily accessable way.

  • to shoot a KAP Documentary Movie that will portrait our artists, their work and the Afghan Artist scene.
    An experienced Afghan film team will visit the artists of KABUL ART PROJECT at their working places, studios or at home to speak about their art and life, their motivation and working conditions. Our artists will talk about their sources for inspiration and show us their favourite places. The viewer will get a private glimpse into the artists' world and the very young Contemporary Afghan art scene, that has been developing just within the past 12 years. The viewers will be introduced to an unknown side of Afghanistan and will be able to connect with the artists' lives and their experiences of being an artist through a lifetime at war.
    Details: ca. 45 mins,, Dari/Pashto with English subtitles

  • to organize further KAP exhibitions
    Exhibitions, the connection to the real world! We have already exhibited 60 artworks by our artists (oil paintings, watercolor paintings and drawings) in Germany, and these artworks are meant to travel through Germany and Europe. We'd like to extend the exhibition to 100 pieces and organize some major KABUL ART PROJECT exhibitions in Germany, Italy, UK and more.
    Your support will help us with the transport, framing of the artworks, possible rents and helpers for at least two further exhibitions.

  • All of this will have a big impact to the presence and prominence of Afghan Art and Artists and will improve the way KABUL ART PROJECT can support and promote the Artists!
    We will reach much more people, who will see Afghanistan and its people with different eyes and who will hopefully be inspired, too.



If we reach our funding goal, every supporter will get a free download of our documentary film, expected in May/June 2015!

If we don't reach the goal, we will work in this order:
1. KAP Artist Books & Online Shop
2. KAP Exhibitions
3. KAP Documentary Film.

Here are some of our perks! (Please see Perk details on the right side)
A selection of artworks and other KABUL ART PROJECT images can be viewed here in the gallery, or on our website and facebook page














Art is Freedom.

Contemporary Art from Afghanistan is very young. Until twelve years ago most of artistic work was prohibited by the Taliban regime under penalty of death. Contemporary Art had to be re-discovered by the new generation of Afghan artists. Supporting Afghan Art is not only a support to the artists, but it is an enrichment to everyone, who didn't know of it before.

KABUL ART PROJECT wants to support Afghan artists on their way as much as possible. With your help we can walk step two of our mission.

The Art, especially Contemporary Art, is still viewed with scepticism by the Afghan society, devalued, sometimes disrespected and the performing of Art may still pose a danger to the artists and their families. Within the last 18 months some of our artists experienced several cases of deliberate destruction of their artworks, even by government institutions such as the National Gallery in Kabul, and some artists were attacked and threatened by Taliban.


KABUL ART PROJECT has supported and promoted talented Afghan artists since January 2013.
We have become one of the most present platforms to connect Afghan Contemporary Artists to foreign media, exhibitors and private art collectors, or simply lovers of art, where Afghan art was greatly underrepresented before.

We have exhibited original paintings and drawings by our 27 artists from Afghanistan in Germany with more exhibitions to come, and we promote their artworks on a daily basis through social media and our website. New contacts and connections are being made, foreign media and exhibitors reach out to our artists through us. Just through our website and facebook we could handle a good number of art sales from Afghanistan to Canada, the United States, Europe and inside Afghanistan.

Now that we have built a solid community of art loving followers, we want to take the next step to reach a larger public. With your support we will be able to publish a series of Artist Books and our first Catalogue, shoot a Documentary Film portraying our artists, organize more Exhibitions in Europe and open our Online Store.


Ali Akhlaqi
Hamed Hassanzada
Shamsia Hassani
Malina Suliman
Hamdullah Arbab
Rashed Rahmani
Wali Askarzai
Akram Ati
Qasem Foushanji
Arif Bahaduri
Baqir Ahmadi
Tamanna Barekzai
Assadullah Baran Bromand
Mumtaz Khan Chopan
Azim Fakhri
Ayatullah Ahmadi
Mohsen Hossaini
Amin
Zainab Haidary
Azizullah Hazara
Nabila Horakhsh
Taqi Mehran
Moshtari Hilal
Jahan Ara Rafi
Meena Saifi
Ali Yaser Shoaib
Faiqa Sultani

Share, share, share this campaign wherever you can!
Please invite friends, your boss, your aunt and everyone who might want to support our project.

If you prefer another payment method instead of PayPal and credit card, please contact me at info@kabulartproject.com

story:
Who is HIM?

Hello art enthusiasts, my name is Boden Him, a Studio Art grad from Cal State Long Beach. With a deep appreciation for the arts, I am launching my first solo exhibition themed around musicians and influential artists. The gallery will feature a comprehensive collection of oil paintings, charcoal portraits, digital and mixed media. 

 

Why I'm here.

I am one of those starving and malnourished artist. I am here to ask for your help in funding my first exhibit. Your contributions will help provide the necessary elements to bring this show to life. $1,500 needs to be raised by April 2. A portion of gallery sales will be donated to a local charity, Taryn's Hope 4 Life.

The proceeds will enable me to provide you with prints of my work, food, refreshments, prizes, and cover the cost of staging. 

Prints=$1,000

Display accessories=$200

Art supplies=$200

Refreshments=$100

 

By the way, you're all invited!

Saturday, April 6th, 6PM - 10PM

Forever Ashbury / Movement
1826-1828 E Broadway
Long Beach, CA 90802

 

What's the purpose?

This project almost didn't happen. Over the years, I've been constantly urged by family and friends to assemble an art show. We finally kicked this event into fruition in December 2012. Little did I know of the harsh news that lied ahead that month. My whole design department got laid off. Soon after that, the original venue that was going to host the show had to be shut down. This was a plan heading in a bad direction. 

Weeks after hearing about my misfortune, a group of friends reached out to me. The staff at Forever Ashbury/Movement offered their flagship store as a venue.

I've been truly fortunate to meet so many inspiring artists from all walks of life.  Their work has helped catapult my desire to create art over the years.  I've seen the impact it has made on people, and as a result, I know first hand that art has a great spot in people's lives.  This gathering will take place at the Forever Ashbury/Movement Flagship Store in downtown Long Beach, CA. The event is simply designed for creatives to come together, network and have a groovy time.

 

Your contribution.

Whether you think so or not, anything you decide to do will make a great impact.  If you're unable to make any monetary contributions, you can help spread the word by simply sharing this with your friends and family.  A quick Facebook post, Twitter tweet or Instagram snapshot will go a long way.  I sincerely appreciate you stopping by. 

-Boden

 

 

www.TheArtOfHim.com

www.ForeverAshbury.com

www.MovementLBC.com

www.TarynsHope4Life.com (Currently unavailable)

story:
Visible Bodies: Transgender Narratives Retold - Twin Cities

We believe it is important to subvert the common narrative told about trans* people through mainstream media and popular culture. Visible Bodies is about trans* voices telling trans* stories. Oftentimes, the common narrative contains images and stories that are over simplified and stereotyped. Our goal is to show the diversity, complexity, and beauty of our community. 

This project is empowerment. We are making space for people to hear trans* voices and see trans* bodies. 

What We Do

Visible Bodiesis a trans* community art initiative.  Every participant in our project has had a photo or video taken in a way that represents their gender or transition -- whatever that means to them.  In addition, each participant has written a short personal piece as a caption to their photograph or video.

Our goal is to provide a platform for trans* people of all different walks of life to tell their stories. We seek to empower our own community, and educate people outside of our community.  

Where We Started

Visible Bodies began as a student project at the University of California, San Diego. The goal was to create a body of work that would make the campus LGBT Resource Center more welcoming to trans* students. The response to the San Diego project was overwhelmingly positive. You can see samples of the press through the following links: Advocate article, Huffington Post.  

What We Need

We need $4000 to realize the full potential of this project. Here's the breakdown of where the money will go:

  • An 11x14 print will cost us $7 and the matte and frame will cost us $42 so your $50 donation will allow for one printed and framed photo and story to make it into the exhibit.
  • Total, we are hoping to include 40 narratives in this project.
  • 40 narratives will cost approximately $2000 to exhibit.
  • Our photographers and other artistic collaborators plan to put in at least 150 hours to make this project a success. We would like to pay them at least minimum wage. This will cost approximately $1200.
  • The remainder of the funds will go towards rewards, shipping costs, the indiegogo fee, and promotional costs. 

Stretch Goal - $5000

  • If we exceed our goal, we will launch a guerrilla posturing campaign to reach a wider audience.
  • We would also really like to pay our photographers and artistic collaborators more than minimum wage.
  • The more money we raise, the more narratives we can include in the project.
  • Extra funds will be filtered back to the national Visible Bodies organization to launch projects in other cities.

Make a Difference

Your donation will empower the trans* community and educate those outside of the community. Help us make it happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Trans* and interested in modeling? Visit our website and fill out an interest form!
  • Share this site on Facebook, via email, word of mouth, phone calls, twitter, tumblr, put it on your holiday wish list…GET THE WORD OUT!
  • Want to help organize? We need help promoting, writing grants, fundraising, framing, and all the other things that go into making this project happen. Email visiblebodiesmpls@gmail.com to get involved.

Who We Are

Visible Bodies: Twin Cities is made up of Queer volunteer organizers in Minneapolis/St Paul. Some of the organizers involved are:

  • Adja Gildersleve - an empowered brown&queer activist/videographer shooting for Justice.
  • Garrett Drew - a trans and queer academic, organizer, and rabble-rouser.
  • Jie Wronski-Riley - a student, photographer, and community organizer.
  • Rebecca Lawrence - a queer professional photographer and community organizer.
  • Sara Watts - a trans female, grad student in mental health therapy, and community organizer.

THANK YOU!

*trans - We utilize this umbrella term to include people who identify outside of cisgender identities.

story:
Story: 

Escape is an animated dance film piece capturing the emotions of refugees. It’s inspired by the Khmer Rouge that affected many families such as my own. It highlights the fight, grief, and struggle for freedom refugees had to experience. Stories of survivors are powerful and must be told. The piece will explore the conversation between animation and dance. In the animation department at MassArt, it will stand as a unique conversation between animation, art, and dance.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Funds will be towards two dancers to choreograph, rehearse, and film the production. As well as hiring a composer for the piece. 
  • By donating, your name will appear in the credits, an invitation to the live performances, and a digital copy of the filmed version. 
  • If the goal is not met, dancers and composers will be paid less than what they deserve. 

The Impact

Refugee stories need to told!! Support young artists who have a voice!

About Me:

Lisa Lam is an Asian American storyteller and filmmaker in the Boston area. If she’s not working on art, she’s songwriting or “dancing” in her Boston apartment. She enjoys how vulnerable and personal she can get with combining art, music, and dance together.
She loves to incorporate texture, story, and refreshing effects into her style. In the summer, she spends her time as a Park Ranger at Lowell National Historical Park.

SHARE TO FRIENDS!

story:
The Idea

  • After a few years out of college and some initial struggles, I am able to focus on what I love and cannot live without - my art!
  • This campaign is to help raise funds for the canvas, paint, supplies, travel, and lodging for the week-long trip. The funds will strictly be used for the art supplies to complete the life-sized project as well as the trip itself.
  • Your help will allow me to fund this painting that could lead to valuable connections and opportunities in the art world.

I can't even express my thanks to all of you for even considering helping.

The Supplies

The piece will require:

  • Large canvases for the painting itself
  • Gesso to prime the large-scale canvas
  • Acrylic paints and painting supplies (I will be using what I have to supplement this piece, but I definitely do not have enough paint to make it the whole way through!)
  • Painter's Tape (lots of it!)
  • Some grocery funds to help out those who open their homes to me!
  • Subway funds, food, and the train ticket to get to NYC!

Why am I doing this residency?

This venture is a way to get my name out there while building an incredible gallery show with my fellow artists. The opportunity to show in New York with an established group is an experience that doesn't come along every day. Though I do not expect to gain anything financially from this venture, the connections and experiences are invaluable. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share my campaign if you feel comfortable helping out - this means the world to me.
  • If you live in New York City or nearby, I hope to see you at the show September 2nd & 3rd!

After a few years out of college and some initial struggles, I am able to focus on what I love and cannot live without - my art!
This campaign is to help raise funds for the canvas, paint, supplies, travel, and lodging for the week-long trip. The funds will strictly be used for the art supplies to complete the life-sized project as well as the trip itself.
Your help will allow me to fund this painting that could lead to valuable connections and opportunities in the art world.

I can't even express my thanks to all of you for even considering helping.

The Supplies
The piece will require:

Large canvases for the painting itself
Gesso to prime the large-scale canvas
Acrylic paints and painting supplies (I will be using what I have to supplement this piece, but I definitely do not have enough paint to make it the whole way through!)
Painter's Tape (lots of it!)
Some grocery funds to help out those who open their homes to me!
Subway funds, food, and the train ticket to get to NYC!


Why am I doing this residency?
This venture is a way to get my name out there while building an incredible gallery show with my fellow artists. The opportunity to show in New York with an established group is an experience that doesn't come along every day. Though I do not expect to gain anything financially from this venture, the connections and experiences are invaluable. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share my campaign if you feel comfortable helping out - this means the world to me.
If you live in New York City or nearby, I hope to see you at the show September 2nd & 3rd!

story:
Let's go on a baking adventure!

Hey there! It's Mel and Sara, back with another enamel pin adventure! This time we're venturing into one of our childhood loves: Pokemon (and our dreams of becoming a master).

It's probably no secret to anyone that knows us that we both have a love of storytelling, for finding sweets and doodling these goofball creatures, so over the past few months we've been thinking up enamel pin designs that we hope everyone will enjoy. Also for the first time in Indiegogo, you can find some new apparel that we've been designing if we reach the goals! 

To kick off our adventures, we're also introducing Milo and Rylee, both of whom will be featured in a mini-series of comic strips. There's a bit more about them further down, but join them as they stumble their way through the Pokemon world and we hope that you'll enjoy these adventures and our newest designs. 

Behold, the Pokedex! Bulbasuar, Squirtle, Charmander and Pikachu are the original starters.

NOTE: Please click on tiers to drop down information!! It is automatically collapsed.

The Basics:

We're starting out with the four starter Pokemon completely unlocked. A base pledge of one (1) pin will get you your choice of any of them. In the stretch goals, you'll see more additional pins we can unlock by breaking these goals. Any of the "Sets" will have a choice of any of the pins, unlocked or not.

The pins come on either holographic backing cards or if you get the Gym Leader tier, you can get them on a custom designed card with Pokemon team slots, signed by Sara. It reads like the old trainer teams!

The two shirt designs and the scarf can be either purchased individually as a separated pledge, or can be found in the "Food of Galar [Complete Set]" (which makes it basically come for free!). They are separate pledges because they'll be shipped separately (likely sooner for shirts, TBD on the scarves!).

The shirts are either mainly triblends, which are a durable but light material that's super soft. It'll basically be like cuddling an Eevee all the time! We have unisex options for both tees in the colors pictured above, plus an additional women's fit shirt for the ALL CP & NO IV shirt that's teal ice colored.

The scarf below is made of modal fabric (soft but warm!). It's a long scarf, measuring either 65 cm x 180cm or 65 cm or 200 cm (we're still debating on the final length, but these are both standards!). We'll post samples of these scarves once they're in but do not they'll be a bit later than the shirts.

Some important reminders:

> Indiegogo pulls money immediately, but if you want to increase your pledge later it's no problem! We use a company called BackerKit for post-campaign management, and you'll be able to add extra pins at campaign pricing there (but only what is unlocked).

> There will be a survey after the campaign! Nothing long, we promise! You pick your choices for pins (or charms) through BackerKit, NOT now. All clothing, if unlocked, can be purchased there as well. We will have size charts listed within the survey.

The Backing Cards:

We've designed some specialty backing cards just for the campaign. They have a holographic shimmer to them, featuring 6 different pokeball designs. For any pledge up to the 6 mark, you'll get a random selection of cards. We hope you'll collect them all!

Stretch Goals:

In typical fashion, we couldn't design just four adorable Pokemon food pins... nope, we have 16 unlockable choices! See below for at what goal they unlock. 

Social Goals:

In addition to the standard stretch goals which are impacted by the funding directly, we also have social media goals! Help boost & share the relevant posts (linked below) which unlock the following charms as additional delights. They can be swapped in place of any pin, and are also added for free to the Food of Galar (Complete Set) pack.

Links:  Tumblr  |  Instagram (unlocked)  |  Twitter 

Meet Milo & Rylee!

Milo, the 21-year-old Pokemon novice, and Rylee, the 11-year-old sugar enthusiast and walking-Pokemon-encyclopedia trainer, are part of our newest mini comic series, traveling around the regions discovering new Pokemon, having adventures and solving mysteries... all while learning to live with approximately 2 cents to their name.

In our comics (featured alongside the pins), you'll be able to see them miss about 99% of their ball throws, catch all of the wrong Pokemon, barely avoid disaster and only ruin about 50% of the meals they make. We hope you enjoy their humorous-but-dangerous adventures as much as we've loved making them.

About the Creators:

Mel and Sara are the owners of the Alchemy Art Group. It has two branches – our individual projects (like this, Essence of Red and others) where we travel around the United States showing our work at conventions (also enlisting some of our members to do commissioned pieces), and our "collective" branch which includes many creative members that contribute to community projects. The latter includes larger scale projects including Tyrian Tarot and Echoes of Thunder.

This is our fourth crowdfunded project (with making almost over 20,000 pins to date), and we're really excited to change it up with these new designs. We really hope this one is a success!!

Funding Information:

As enamel pins are one of our main productions, we're quite familiar with the process and ready to get this started! One of the pins (which has the shiny variant) has arrived, and you'll be able to see that in the updates! 

We're quite certain of our timelines and the quality of our pins, as well as the time and requirements necessary to get them out to you! We're happy to answer any questions about this via email (alchemyartgroup@gmail.com).

 

If there are any adjustments to the schedule, we'll inform everyone as soon as we're able.

Risks and Challenges:

As with any crowdfunded project (and any item that is subject to preorders), there are inherent risks by funding them in advance not knowing what schedule pitfalls that may occur. We've created four crowdfunded campaigns now and are ready with manufacturers and a timeframe.

If any delays do occur, we'll relay them within a timely manner, and we're always available for questions and concerns at our email: alchemyartgroup@gmail.com.

story:
Our Story

Not long after Burning Man 2014, two new friends sat across each other at the bar discussing their futures in the burner community.  One friend turned to the other and asked, "if you could do anything this year, just for fun, what would it be?"  From this question, and their friendship, The Deep was born.

The Deep is a story of a misfit band of burners brought together by a common dream - a giant, luminous jellyfish.  Armed with our mutual affinity for deep sea life, a handful of useful skills and past *experiences*, and apparently too much free time on our hands, we embarked on a mission to create the dreamiest mutant vehicle on the East Coast.

The journey hasn't been easy, but it's been fun as hell.  Our build plan is on pace to meet our goal of premiering The Deep at Burning Man 2015, and with a little more help from you, we'll be able to finish this fantasy gift for the DC Burning Man community!

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to our successful fundraising event in May, we have already raised enough money to fund the vehicle and most of the materials for the jellyfish.  (Yay!)  Now, we only need to raise $2,000 more to fund the following essentials for the build:

  • The Deep's sound system - $400
  • The vehicle lights and supplemental battery - $300
  • Building materials for the vehicle's coral reef bodywork (steel pole holders, wire mesh, PVC, foam pieces, paint, adhesive, etc.) - $300
  • Monthly warehouse fees and transport costs to Burning Man - $1000
If you help us raise more than our $2,000 base goal, we can afford to go all out and add these exciting possibilities to The Deep:
  • Side outrigger pontoons and guardrails to support the vehicle and allow passengers to ride on the top level safely - $200 - $300
  • Additional lights and building materials to complete the full "coral reef chariot" vision for the vehicle body - $500
  • Even a second jellyfish to create a "dueling dancing jellyfish" vehicle! - $700

What Are you Waiting For? Be Part of History, Man!

For years, DC burners have wanted to build more mutant vehicles, but due to limited maker space and the high cost of transport to Burning Man, very few mutant vehicle dreams have been realized from this otherwise thriving community.  The Deep will be a symbol of beauty and pride for DC for years to come.  

This is a community gift!  The more successful our fundraising, the more fun The Deep will be to party with and ride on at Burning Man, local festivals, and DC events!  So please contribute what you can and share this campaign with more friends!

We'll see you dancing under the jellyfish!

story:
Hello My Dears, 

I'm Lauren Elizabeth, writer/actress based in NYC. This campaign is as dear to me as it is humbling. Next month, I embark on a very sacred journey: my first trip to Ireland. Since I was very small, I have felt a sacred kinship to all things Gaelic. At long last, I am going to find out why. I am going to recharge my batteries, artistic, spiritual and physical after several very long years of toil sans vacation. Once in Ireland / Eire, I will hike, write, explore the lands of James Joyce, W B Yeats, and the Irish theatre. I will traverse the lands Jim Sheridan, Daniel Day-Lewis and Neil Jordan pay homage to in film. I will walk the lands of "Ryan's Daughter". The lands immortalized by Van Morrison, U2 and the Chieftains, heroes all to me. 

Here's the thing: I am a waitress. NYC is expensive and a couple of unforeseen issues in the past few months have made it difficult to save (hello car trouble, hello healthcare!:) I gratefully and humbling am asking for donors to contribute funds which will enable me to:

-Travel within Ireland via rented car (drive down Atlantic coast "Into the West"!)  and public transportation

-Rent cottage(s) and lodgings in Dublin, Galway, and Ballinskelligs (County Kerry) and the Midlands

-Purchase Poloroid film prior to departure in both black & white and color for my two cameras - the Polaroids SX-70 and Sun 600, respectively, allowing me to photograph copiously to document trip and nurture long time love of instant film medium! 

- Pay bills that do not wait and do not forgive:)

Thank you from my heart and soul in advance!

grá agus solas (love and light), 

Lauren Elizabeth

story:
NEW STRETCH GOAL: $2,000! READ MORE BELOW.


Short(ish) Summary

My name is Mickey Alice Kwapis. I am a taxidermist, craftsperson, and jewelry designer living in Chicago, Illinois with a dog, three cats, two rats, and an adult human. My work focuses on the relationship between humans and the natural world and my taxidermy work aims to educate people as to why preservation of species is important for the future. I do not kill animals and you can read all about that here. Please do not leave angry comments out of a lack of understanding.

This campaign was started as a means to raise money for new jewelry equipment so I can expand upon the themes already present in my work, but with more tools and resources at my disposal. Now that the second stretch goal of $1,500 has been met, I have added a new stretch goal of $2,000 to continue raising money for raw materials as well as donations for the following cause:

Because of the themes already present in my current work (pieces of which comprise the reward tiers for this campaign), and in order to give back to the dying populations from which I draw my inspiration, fifteen percent (15%) of proceeds from this campaign are being donated to honeybee colony collapse research. The rest will go towards purchasing materials and tools for jewelry fabrication, soldering, plating, and more. If the new stretch goal is met, $300 automatically gets donated to bee research - details below.

What I Need & What You Get

With this campaign, I am hoping to raise $2,000 for new jewelry equipment and materials. This includes a setup for cutting and hammering ring bands, annealing and pickling jewelry elements, soldering, polishing, and all of the materials for projects including raw metals, solder, saw blades, flux, and more. While there are cheaper things I could purchase at a hardware store to do a few of these tasks, I am aware of how quickly I will outgrow (and dispose of) them and I believe that purchasing a full, professional set-up will be much less wasteful in the long run. In addition to these funds covering costs of tools and equipment, I will use anything beyond that to purchase raw materials and a shelving unit to house all of it in my tiny studio.

No matter how much money I raise here, 8% of the total automatically goes towards payment processing. Since my rewards draw inspiration from (and in some cases, include victims of) colony collapse disorder in bee hives, I am also donating 15% of all proceeds to honeybee colony collapse disorder research at the National Resources Defense Council.

So what are the perks for you?

Contribute $55 or more and receive one of my signature honeybee necklaces. This necklace retails for $70 and is comprised of a glass vial with a real honeybee in it. Each honeybee was found deceased in my yard after our hive succumbed to colony collapse disorder. I suspend the preserved honeybee in a mix of my favorite taxidermy solutions along with some gold leaf flakes, triple-seal the whole thing, and cap it with a spent bullet casing gifted to me by my grandfather. If only ten more people bought this reward tier, the new stretch goal would be met! Also includes a hand-written thank-you note.

Contribute $15 or more and receive a pair of raw gemstone earrings, made with either chalcopyrite, pyrite, or quartz. I'm fairly sure you can include a note to me with your donation, but if not, please send an email to hello@mickeyalicekwapis.com with your preference on gemstone. These retail for $15-20 per pair and your order will also include a hand-written thank-you note.

Contribute $5 or more and receive a hand-written postcard thanking you for your contribution. These have been collected from my travels over the last five years and come from all over the world.

Please make sure to include a valid shipping address with any reward tier. More details on estimated ship dates are below. If you do not choose a reward when making your donation, you will not receive one.

If I reach more than $2,000 I will still continue to donate 15% of all proceeds to honeybee research.

The Impact

But wait, you say! Can't you just save up and purchase this equipment? Can't you get a small business loan? Like the rest of you, I have bills and responsibilities which makes it hard to save up. I only use money from jewelry sales to purchase new jewelry equipment, and usually I'd rather use my Etsy money to pay off bills. Small business loans don't really come in amounts as tiny as my initial goal, and the interest rates right now are ridiculous. Instead of any of the options listed above, I am offering the same things in this campaign as could be bought in my Etsy store, but at discounted rates so you can purchase something you love, get a discount, contribute to an artist, and help save honeybees all at the same time. This way, I can stick to my rule of only using money from jewelry sales to buy new jewelry equipment.

Not everyone likes the idea of crowd-funding, so if you don't, feel free to purchase any of these items from my Etsy shop (but at a higher rate).


Risks & Challenges

There really are no ways that this could go wrong. Since I already made the goal (thanks guys!!!!) in less than twelve hours, everything else is just icing on the cake. All additional funds past the initial $650 will be split the same way (8% in processing fees to IndieGoGo, 15% to the NRDC, and the rest to raw materials) and will allow me to have a larger amount of raw materials to work with for my first few design runs. Since all of the rewards listed are things I already make (rather than promising reward requiring a purchase of equipment, trial and error while using it, and eventually shipping out product) I will have no issue making and delivering the rewards listed in this campaign by the date promised.

Because I don't know how many orders I will get from this campaign, I am putting an estimated ship date of July 1st on all orders to give myself a little extra time to fulfill everything. While realistically I will definitely be able to send out postcards and earrings before then, there is always a possibility of an overwhelming response and I want to ensure that I can get everyone taken care of by the date I have promised.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't interested in a honeybee necklace or a pair of earrings, don't fret! Social media exists for a reason - it's a really great way to make your voice heard. If you want to, you can share this to your friends and followers. If you have a friend who's really into bees, send them this link!

I think that's it. Let's do this thing!

xoxo

Mickey

Portraits by Jim Vondruska and Alicia Brianne Photo, respectively. Product photography done in-house.

Small business loans don't really come in amounts as tiny as my initial goal, and the interest rates right now are ridiculous. Instead of any of the options listed above, I am offering the same things in this campaign as could be bought in my Etsy store, but at discounted rates so you can purchase something you love, get a discount, contribute to an artist, and help save honeybees all at the same time. This way, I can stick to my rule of only using money from jewelry sales to buy new jewelry equipment.
Not everyone likes the idea of crowd-funding, so if you don't, feel free to purchase any of these items from my Etsy shop (but at a higher rate).
   Risks & Challenges There really are no ways that this could go wrong. Since I already made the goal (thanks guys!!!!) in less than twelve hours, everything else is just icing on the cake. All additional funds past the initial $650 will be split the same way (8% in processing fees to IndieGoGo, 15% to the NRDC, and the rest to raw materials) and will allow me to have a larger amount of raw materials to work with for my first few design runs. Since all of the rewards listed are things I already make (rather than promising reward requiring a purchase of equipment, trial and error while using it, and eventually shipping out product) I will have no issue making and delivering the rewards listed in this campaign by the date promised.
Because I don't know how many orders I will get from this campaign, I am putting an estimated ship date of July 1st on all orders to give myself a little extra time to fulfill everything. While realistically I will definitely be able to send out postcards and earrings before then, there is always a possibility of an overwhelming response and I want to ensure that I can get everyone taken care of by the date I have promised.

    Other Ways You Can Help If you aren't interested in a honeybee necklace or a pair of earrings, don't fret! Social media exists for a reason - it's a really great way to make your voice heard. If you want to, you can share this to your friends and followers. If you have a friend who's really into bees, send them this link!
   I think that's it. Let's do this thing!xoxoMickeyPortraits by Jim Vondruska and Alicia Brianne Photo, respectively. Product photography done in-house.

story:
Short Summary

I am a video and music producer, writer, engineer, and performer. Throughout the years I have had my fair share of everything music related. I've played in bands, ran my own sound equipment for shows, ran my own recording studio, opened my own all ages venue, helped manage a huge team to put on a 2 day music festival, and the list goes on. If you name a job, I've probably done it.

Now is the time for me to take my sharpened talents, expand upon them, and put them to use on bigger projects. I want to go to LA because that is where my industry is. I've been attempting to take this trip for years, but I keep folding under circumstances that are out of my control. I currently have enough assets to sell off, that will fund my trip, for about 1 week, and then I will be out of money.

Your contribution will help me get stable in a place that is very expensive to live. When I first arrive in LA, I will be staying in Air BnB's, which is basically renting someones couch night by night. This can run anywhere from 20 a day up to 100 a day. Contributions will help me stay sharp, so I can find the network connections that I am searching for. I don't want to be stranded, worrying about how I will scrounge up enough to get my next meal. This is not the mindset that will push me forward, it will make me eager to jump into a situation that may not be the best fit. I want to be wise with my choices and follow my heart.

What I Need & What You Get

I need enough money to get me through at least one month in LA. This money will be spent on travel, room, and board.

The perks to contributors are as unique as my skills. You can select from anything like, photography, video, music production, and audio engineering.

Even if the goal isn't met, I will still be taking this trip.

 

Risks & Challenges

I've heard it before, people who chase these dreams are facing 1 in a million odds that they will be discovered. I completely understand that my chances of being "found" are slim to none.

I don't plan to be found, I plan to lead people to me. I am excellent with communication, and ultimately, I just need to put myself into a position where I am able to show people how I use my talents. Once that moment arrives, everything will be on track.

Other Ways You Can Help

It's as simple as just sharing this campaign. Even if you can't afford any money right now, a simple share may open a door for me. That's why Indiegogo made it so simple to share.

story:
Short Summary

I am a potter, social activist, spoken word poet, and educator. All of these roles are rooted in my childhood.  As a child my first exposure to art was “Graffiti."

Today my graffiti is defacing social inequality. I see my pottery as a process of transforming the ground we walk on into something we eat from;  we search all day for the perfect spot to put it on display. In many ways this transformation of tragedy into triumph is a metaphor for my life’s story.

I have developed a studio practice that fluidly communicates with diverse audiences. This is why working in film is incredibly important. I hope to connect with audiences outside of the ceramics cannon in order to illustrate the places where my work relates to others fields. The medium of film is the most accessible medium for many potential viewers.

The hope is not that we will create a influx of new potters but that folks can see the addagge "you can be anything you want" is true. Pottery is not just for a singular race or culture. It is representative of the human story and the contemporary urban experience needs its own voice. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Your support will go to help us:
    • rent necessary equipment for filming
    • pay for space where we will film
    • pay for editing, and production
  • We have spent much time considering how to bring our vision to life and limiting expenses. 
  • We have many sought-after professionals who are offering their services for very reasonable rates. 

 

  • Our perks will include hand-made ceramics from the artist himself, prints, and even a personal visit with dinner. 
  • If our goal is not reached we will still film and use what's raised to create this proof of concept. 

The Impact

 

  • This film will help encourage:
    • more artists of color to seek careers in the visual arts.
    • Act as an example the everyday barriers people of color face while pursuing their dreams. 
    • This project will not work as a traditional documentary but synthesize the biographical with the artist's performative work. 

Risks & Challenges

  • I am dedicated to seeing this project through and feel confident about achieving a film that will connect with a diverse audience.
  • We are filming in the cold and will work in sometimes unsafe environments. The authenticity of these experiences are important to this production. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share Share Share
  • Are you in Philadelphia and want to be a part of this? We are looking for folks who can help with a variety of tasks.

story:
Garden of Eden in a time of collapse and renewal

Support our build of an immersive garden of Tarot symbolism and artistic guided meditation.

We have been plotting this project for a full year and have been given the opportunity to build it. In this time of self-reflection and action, we feel grateful to build a project intent on internal guidance, sensation, and visual pleasure. We need some financial help to get there, but we hope you will join us in Garden of Eden at the cell theatre, opening in August and running through October (at least). Safety and connecting with immersive art in person in this new age of risk-assessment is our primary goal.

What We Need & What You Get

Ereka Imani Duncan and Jaclyn Atkinson have been creating installations as Dark Matter for 5 years and have been planning this Garden of Eden experience for over a year: a meditational journey through the Tarot via immersive installation. We have many of our basic tools and items covered (and glean much from the trash!) but all art projects come with hard costs. Let us break it down:

  • What we need: Cleaning supplies (for between each visit), Uhaul rental for material transport (like pallets, large paper-mâché, fake grass, and other raw materials), sensory intoxicating plant life (eucalyptus, live moss and plants), raw materials (wood, paint, el-wire and lighting). If we go beyond our goal we would also like to pay a digital artist to help us build a Zoom room tarot reader booth. We would also like to present our distant tarot readers with a financial guarantee for their time.
  • Perks you get: Book your tickets early through donation presale! Stickers! Handmade masks! Handmade moss crystal earrings and necklaces! Woodblock prints by Jaclyn Atkinson! Bribery Picnic Pie!
  • The cell theatre has blessed us with a beautiful space, administrative support, and staff, but we need money to make it run beautifully. All events and entry to the Garden will be split with the cell theatre. 

Support the arts / Shadow work

In a New York that is boxed up, with Broadway lights off, Cirque at bankruptcy, gatherings limited, and galleries scrambling, we are facing a city full of possibilities for new creativity, but still caged in impossible structures of wealth and real-estate. Aside from health risks and financial instability, we stand at a revolutionary tide, Black Lives Matter and we have been building this project fueled by the desire for change and renewed urgency rooted in the belief that we must all go through shadow work, individually and as a country, to build a better future.
Shadow work is sifting through the unconscious, the unknown within, to tend your own garden and glean a deeper understanding of self and path. We find the Tarot an important tool for this process. We have focused our energies on making this installation a form of meditation and reflection, believing that the Tarot can be used as a tool for processing and to shift understanding. 

  • Come with an understanding of the Tarot or with nothing in mind but openness, either experience will be valid,
  • We believe that internal progress can be spawned by self-questioning and think of Tarot as a tool to explore that. We all have work to do.
  • Support if you can, we need help to make this space blossom. We know that there are many important causes to support right now, and we hope that you can and will still do so. No one will be turned away for lack of funds to this experience—we are planning with accessibility in mind.

Risks & Challenges in a Time of Covid and Art Crisis

Do you miss seeing art experiences in person as much as we do? Worried about returning to an immersive environment while still cautiously accessing your risk? We have spent time thinking about how to move forward. We got you, here's our plan for now:

  • You book a time to visit, ensuring that you are the ONLY person (or quara-couple) in the experience at a time. Our space guardian greets you masked and remains at a safe 6 ft distance. All other interactions happen through sensory and digital—It's just you and the space.
  • We have limited the items you touch and wipe off each of these items between visits. We request all guests keep their masks on.
  • Please come with a mask and be dedicated to social distancing practices.

Other Ways You Can Help Our Project

If you can't financially contribute, but still want to help:

  • Tell your friends: Help us get the word out to get us funded (you can use the Indiegogo share tools)! 
  • Message us for a discounted ticket to the event. We do not wish to turn away anyone for financial troubles and believe that this artful meditation should be available for all who desire it—accessibility is key—especially in these times. 

Thank you and be well!
-Ereka & Jaclyn

Photos of events in profile photographed by Walter Wlodarczyk, used with permission.

story:
Honduran Murals for Social Impact

"Las personas son las únicas capaces de transformar la sociedad."

Update: With all of your support, love and positivity, we have reached our initial goal in 72 hours! This is amazing!!! Due to the fact that our campaign is prefixed to end at January 31, and we cannot receive the funds until then, we've decided to keep going! So all the additional funds that we raise will now go to NEW mural projects, this is at the request from the muralists. THANK YOU! Let's keep sharing this and raise as much money as we can for these incredible people~

Why Should You Care?

Poor Education System

Honduras is one of the poorest countries in Latin America and has the world's highest murder rate. More than half of the population lives in poverty and per capita income is one of the lowest in the region. The increased productivity needed to break Honduras' persistent high poverty rate depends, in part, on further improvements in educational attainment. Although primary-school enrollment is near 100%, educational quality is poor, the drop-out rate and grade repetition remain high, and teacher and school accountability is low. 

Honduras is the Murder Capital of the World

Guns are responsible for over 80 percent of homicides in Honduras, one of the highest rates of gun homicide in Latin America. Every day 20 people are murdered and only 2% of criminal cases end in conviction. Honduras places third for the largest quantity of violent deaths among adolescents, due to the fact that a large quantity of its young people are involved in criminal activity and the drug trade. The reason so many youth are involved in criminal activity is because only 30% of Honduran youth go to high school and therefore the informal sector is the fastest way to make money.

Culture of Apathy

Honduran society has become incredibly indifferent to the corruption and overload of violence, that no one feels like their voices matter anymore. This culture of apathy combined with very little opportunities for youth, has also fueled criminal activity. 


Our Project Summary

This project will fund two social justice murals. One with talk about the effects gun violence has on Honduran youth and its society, and the other will talk about the education system and the struggles youth have to achieving their goals.  

The project will be run by two honduran muralists, Luis Vasquez and Oscar O'hara, and will incorporate the help of honduran youth to paint the mural. It is important we involve youth in the conversation as well as to teach them skills in mural painting, which can be a valuable trade.

This project also aims to give voice to Honduran youth, change negative stereotypes about Honduran youth and spark candid conversations about societal issues occurring in Honduras--ultimately breaking Honduras' culture of apathy.

Is it safe? Yes. The muralists will not be in any harm for doing these murals, and it is legal. We have permission to paint these walls. The effects of gun violence mural will be painted in Choluteca and the other mural about education will be in Namasigue, in the high school.


About the Muralists

  • My name is Emilie Romero. From 2008-2010, I served in the Peace Corps in southern Honduras, where I worked on youth empowerment programs using art as my medium. I have a MA in International Affairs, with a concentration in Media and Culture from The New School University. You can learn more about me at www.emilieromeroportfolio.com and I am helping fund this mural project for my former colleagues. I worked with Luis Vasquez and Oscar O'hara when they were first starting out to do several large scale social justice murals in my Peace Corps town.  Since my departure they have taken mural painting to another level, teaching youth and painting murals all over Honduras and in Costa Rica, inspiring real dialogues through art. They are some of my favorite people, and are extremely hard workers and incredibly progressive.

  • Luis Vasquez has a special heart for at-risk youth, because he himself was once on drugs, unemployed and homeless. He was fortunate to find a group of artists who taught him how to paint, and he found that painting helped him regain his self-esteem and drop his vices. Luis is amazing with youth and really enjoys teaching as much as he does painting. Luis has a high school degree in industrial mechanics and is now studying to get a BA in Human Resources at the University in Choluteca. He and Oscar have painted murals for Oxfam, Plan International and often paint for an NGO started in southern Honduras by young muralists like themselves. Luis' goal is to one day start his own NGO to teach at-risk youth art techniques that can then be used to start small businesses. 

  • Oscar O'Hara first started drawing at the age of 10. He was very attracted to graffiti often used by gangs in Honduras. He was tempted to join a gang to continue his love for art there, but fortunately was swayed to join a group that was teaching at-risk youth mural painting. That is where he met Luis, and for over six years and they have been painting murals dedicated to inspiring social change.  He works with the Casa De Cultura in Honduras and also attends college. He is really an amazing person with a great sense of humor, and one of my best friends from Honduras. 

What We Need & What You Get

I want to make this as transparent as possible. I had Oscar and Luis send me budgets of how much the materials would cost to do the two murals. Overall costs are $1200.00.

  • Art Resources: We need to raise $600 dollars for all the painting materials, brushes, paints, special coats to protect the wall, buckets, etc. 
  • Commission and Stipend for Muralists: We need to raise an additional $600 to to make sure these muralists get paid for their work, since most of the time they are volunteers. This will also cover transportation costs and a daily stipend for food. 
  • What you get...You get to be part of an art movement, and also get to feel like you are empowering youth to do something that will impact other people to start social change.

The Impact:

  • Muralism often has been a way for artists to express social injustices occurring in society. My friends have told me that they want to do more than just paint pretty murals with flowers. They want their murals to ignite a dialogue around social change. This is definitely our long term goal for this project.
  • The impact that this project will have is to empower young people to take ownership over a project and to feel like not only are they learning new skills, but they are painting something that represents their voice. The voice of young people in Honduras is often silenced, and therefore it is important to give these young people a platform to talk about issues that are affecting them.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Spread the word about our project and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Peace Corps people! Please spread this across our networks!
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to share this on facebook, twitter, etc!

Oscar O'Hara first started drawing at the age of 10. He was very attracted to graffiti often used by gangs in Honduras. He was tempted to join a gang to continue his love for art there, but fortunately was swayed to join a group that was teaching at-risk youth mural painting. That is where he met Luis, and for over six years and they have been painting murals dedicated to inspiring social change.  He works with the Casa De Cultura in Honduras and also attends college. He is really an amazing person with a great sense of humor, and one of my best friends from Honduras. What We Need & What You GetI want to make this as transparent as possible. I had Oscar and Luis send me budgets of how much the materials would cost to do the two murals. Overall costs are $1200.00.

Art Resources: We need to raise $600 dollars for all the painting materials, brushes, paints, special coats to protect the wall, buckets, etc. 

Commission and Stipend for Muralists: We need to raise an additional $600 to to make sure these muralists get paid for their work, since most of the time they are volunteers. This will also cover transportation costs and a daily stipend for food. 

What you get...You get to be part of an art movement, and also get to feel like you are empowering youth to do something that will impact other people to start social change.
The Impact:
Muralism often has been a way for artists to express social injustices occurring in society. My friends have told me that they want to do more than just paint pretty murals with flowers. They want their murals to ignite a dialogue around social change. This is definitely our long term goal for this project.The impact that this project will have is to empower young people to take ownership over a project and to feel like not only are they learning new skills, but they are painting something that represents their voice. The voice of young people in Honduras is often silenced, and therefore it is important to give these young people a platform to talk about issues that are affecting them.Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Spread the word about our project and make some noise about our campaign!
Peace Corps people! Please spread this across our networks!
You can use the Indiegogo share tools to share this on facebook, twitter, etc!

story:
Bob and I have been building whimisical creations for a few years now. The first incarnation of The Red Couch was a human powered paddlewheel boat. We have successfully travelled the Red Couch paddlewheel boat (www.facebook.com/myredcouch) around to many different events, and places. Over the course of the past year, we enjoyed Maker Faire, Lake Sonoma, Camp Tipsy, Trashtastic Boatacular, Clearlake, and others. 

In the next few weeks, we are going to transform the Red Couch into a Handcar for the Wunderkammer: Great Sonoma County Handcar Races www.wunderkammerfestival.com. Shortly thereafter we want to take the Red Couch Railcar up to the Willits Steam Carnivale: www.kineticcarnivale.com . 

Funds raised will purchase square steel tubing, steel wheels, welding supplies, tools, and other essentials for making a sturdy undercarriage for the couch that is propelled by 2 people pedaling. We hope to use as much recycled bike parts as possible, but there will be costs associated with all the building, and a bit for traveling.
